summary_llm:
Nora Helmer, in high spirits on Christmas Eve, returns home with parcels, secretly eating macaroons. Her husband, Torvald Helmer, greets her with affectionate but condescending pet names like "little lark," "little squirrel," and "little spendthrift." He playfully chastises her for spending too much money but then gives her some for Christmas. He firmly expresses his belief that a home should never rely on debt, as it destroys freedom and beauty. Nora hides one of her purchases from him and attempts to subtly ask him for money for herself, which he dismisses, reiterating his view of her as wasteful.

Doctor Rank, a family friend, arrives and goes into Torvald's study. Shortly after, Mrs. Christine Linde, an old school friend of Nora's, arrives. Nora is delighted but shocked by Christine's changed appearance. Christine reveals she is a widow, has lost her mother and her two younger brothers are now self-sufficient, leaving her feeling "unspeakably empty" and in search of work. Nora excitedly shares that Torvald has just been appointed manager of the Bank, ensuring them a large salary and financial security.

Wishing to help Christine, Nora boasts that she can use her influence with Torvald to get Christine a position at the bank. Mrs. Linde, believing Nora to be naive about life's hardships, prompts Nora to reveal a long-held secret: it was Nora, not her father, who secretly borrowed 250 pounds years ago to finance Torvald's life-saving trip to Italy when he was gravely ill. She forged her dying father's signature on the bond to protect him and to avoid burdening Torvald, who despises debt. Nora describes how she has been secretly working odd jobs, like copying, to pay off the debt and its quarterly interest, feeling proud of her efforts "like being a man."

Suddenly, Krogstad, a lawyer, arrives and asks to speak to Torvald on bank business. Mrs. Linde reacts with visible distress upon seeing him. Doctor Rank later identifies Krogstad as a man with a "diseased moral character" who is currently with Helmer, also on bank matters.

Krogstad, who knows Nora's secret, confronts her. He reveals that Torvald plans to dismiss him from his subordinate position at the bank and give it to Mrs. Linde. Krogstad demands that Nora use her influence to ensure he keeps his post and receives a promotion. He threatens to expose her forgery of her father's signature on the bond if she fails to help him. He reveals the date on the bond (October 2nd) is three days after her father's death (September 29th) and that the date, as well as the signature itself, is not her father's handwriting, but one Krogstad believes he recognizes. Nora defiantly admits to forging her father's name, explaining she did it out of love to save Torvald's life and couldn't bear to tell her dying father about her husband's grave condition. Krogstad reminds her that the law cares nothing for motives and warns her that if he loses his position, she will lose hers with him.

After Krogstad leaves, Nora is deeply disturbed by his threats, especially Helmer's earlier pronouncements about deceitful parents corrupting their children. She tells her children not to mention the "stranger man" to their father and isolates herself from them.

Helmer returns and immediately suspects Krogstad has been trying to influence Nora. He chastises Nora for lying about Krogstad's visit and for attempting to intercede on behalf of a "morally diseased" man like Krogstad, who he claims "poisoned his own children with lies and dissimulation." Helmer emphatically states he cannot work with such a person and has already dispatched a letter of dismissal. Nora begs him to recall the letter for their sake and the children's, but it's too late. Helmer, unaware of the forgery, dismisses her fears as "childish nervousness" and promises to shield her from any consequences, asserting his strength as a man.

The next day, Christmas Day, Nora is anxious and agitated, continually checking the letterbox for Krogstad's response. She asks the Nurse if children forget their mothers if they go away, and the Nurse shares that she herself had to put her own child out to strangers to be Nora's nurse. Mrs. Linde arrives to help Nora mend her costume for the upcoming fancy-dress ball. Nora reveals Doctor Rank's terminal illness, which he inherited from his morally corrupt father. Mrs. Linde, suspecting Rank lent Nora the money, prompts Nora to vehemently deny it, though Nora admits she needs to "make an end of it" with the "other one" (Krogstad).

Helmer returns, and Nora, desperate to prevent him from checking the letterbox, insists he must devote himself entirely to helping her rehearse her Tarantella dance for the ball, forbidding him from touching any letters until after the event.

Doctor Rank arrives and, in a poignant conversation, reveals to Nora that he is dying from an inherited spinal disease and will soon send her a card with a black cross as his farewell. He expresses his disdain for "ugliness" and says he will "bar his door" to Helmer when he dies. During this conversation, he confesses his deep love for Nora, which she gently rebuffs.

Krogstad then enters through the back stairs, having received his dismissal letter. He informs Nora that he will keep the forged bond and demand a higher position at the bank, making him Helmer's "right hand." He dismisses Nora's desperate ideas of escape or suicide, assuring her that he would still have power over Helmer. Krogstad then drops a letter detailing Nora's forgery into Helmer's locked letterbox. Nora is horrified.

Mrs. Linde returns and Nora confesses the full extent of her forgery. Nora, in a state of terror, speaks of a "wonderful thing" that is about to happen, asking Christine to be her witness if she goes mad or disappears, affirming that she alone is responsible. Mrs. Linde, upon seeing Krogstad's card, realizes she knows him and rushes out to speak with him, hoping to retrieve the letter.

Nora again distracts Helmer by continuing to practice her Tarantella with him, urging him not to open any letters. Mrs. Linde returns, having failed to retrieve the letter from Krogstad, but informs Nora that Krogstad will return tomorrow. She tells Nora that the truth must come out for a genuine understanding between Nora and Helmer, believing that "concealment and falsehood" make a true relationship impossible. Nora, now counting the hours until the ball ends and Helmer discovers the truth, expresses a strange mixture of dread and anticipation for the "wonderful thing" she believes might happen.

Later that night, after the ball, Mrs. Linde is waiting at the Helmers' house. Krogstad arrives, and they reconcile. Christine explains she left him years ago to support her family, but now she is alone and wants to "join forces" with him, offering herself as a mother to his children and a partner to him. Krogstad is overwhelmed with happiness and agrees, now wanting to redeem himself. He offers to retrieve his letter from Helmer's box, but Mrs. Linde insists he should not. She believes the truth must be revealed so that Nora and Helmer can confront their relationship honestly. Krogstad agrees, saying he will wait for her downstairs.

Helmer brings a resistant Nora home from the ball, praising her dancing but also her "capricious" nature. He expresses a possessive, romantic desire for her. Doctor Rank makes a final appearance, revealing his imminent death with a metaphor about becoming "invisible" at the next ball and asking for a last cigar. Nora lights it for him, and he bids them farewell.

After Rank leaves, Helmer goes to empty the letterbox and finds Krogstad's letter, along with Rank's cards marked with black crosses, signaling his impending death. He reads Krogstad's letter and is enraged, calling Nora a "hypocrite, a liar—worse, worse—a criminal!" He blames her father for her moral failings and laments that she has destroyed his happiness and ruined his future by placing him in Krogstad's power. He declares that their intimate relationship is over, though they must maintain appearances for society. He forbids her from raising the children, stating he cannot trust her with them.

At that moment, a second letter from Krogstad arrives. Helmer reads it and shouts with joy: Krogstad has sent back the forged bond and both letters, expressing regret and repentance due to "a happy change in his life." Helmer is relieved, tears up the incriminating papers, and throws them into the stove. He then "forgives" Nora for her actions, attributing them to her love and "womanly helplessness," and promises to protect and guide her, treating her now as "both wife and child."

Nora, however, has changed into her everyday dress. She sits Helmer down for a serious conversation, stating this is their first real discussion in eight years of marriage. She reveals she has never been happy, only "merry," and that both her father and Helmer have treated her like a "doll," playing with her according to their whims. She declares she must leave to educate herself and understand the world, as she is no longer fit to be his wife or a mother to their children.

Helmer protests, citing her "sacred duties" as a wife and mother and worrying about public opinion. Nora asserts she has "other duties just as sacred"—duties to herself. She no longer believes she is primarily a wife and mother but a "reasonable human being" who must learn to think for herself. She questions the justice of society's laws, which she finds foolish for punishing actions taken out of love.

Helmer accuses her of not loving him anymore. Nora confirms this, stating she realized it tonight when the "wonderful thing" she had hoped for did not happen. She had expected him to bravely take all the blame and sacrifice his honor for her, but instead, he prioritized his own reputation. She concludes that he is not the man she could truly bind herself to.

Nora returns her wedding ring to Helmer and takes back her own. She says she will not see the children, believing they are better off without her in her current state. She states that the "most wonderful thing of all" would be if they both changed so much that their life together could become a "real wedlock," but she no longer believes in such wonders. Nora exits through the hall, shutting the door behind her, leaving Helmer alone and despairing in the empty house.

Here is a very detailed plot summary of the provided text, "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland":

The story begins with **Alice** sitting idly by her sister on a riverbank, feeling bored and sleepy. Her sister is reading a book without pictures or conversations, which Alice finds useless. While pondering whether to make a daisy-chain, Alice suddenly sees a **White Rabbit** with pink eyes run by. What makes this remarkable is that the Rabbit takes a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket, looks at it, and exclaims, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" Driven by curiosity, Alice runs after it across the field and sees it disappear down a large rabbit-hole under a hedge.

Without a moment's hesitation, Alice follows the Rabbit down the hole. The rabbit-hole goes straight like a tunnel before suddenly dipping downwards, sending Alice into a long, slow fall down a very deep well. As she falls, she observes the sides of the well, noticing cupboards, book-shelves, maps, and pictures. She takes down a jar labeled "ORANGE MARMALADE," but it is empty. Not wanting to drop it, she carefully places it in a cupboard. During her descent, Alice calculates how far she's fallen, wonders if she'll fall through the earth, and talks to herself about her cat, Dinah, and whether cats eat bats, becoming drowsy.

Her fall ends with a thump onto a heap of sticks and dry leaves, leaving her unhurt. She quickly jumps up and sees the White Rabbit still ahead, hurrying down a long passage and exclaiming, "Oh my ears and whiskers, how late it’s getting!" Alice chases after it, but when she turns a corner, the Rabbit is gone. She finds herself in a long, low hall lit by lamps, with numerous locked doors. After trying all the doors, she discovers a small three-legged glass table with a tiny golden key. This key is too small for the large doors, but Alice then finds a low curtain, behind which is a small door about fifteen inches high. To her delight, the golden key fits this lock.

Opening the small door, Alice sees a beautiful garden but cannot fit through the tiny passage. She wishes she could shrink. Returning to the table, she finds a bottle labeled "DRINK ME." After prudently checking that it's not marked "poison," she tastes the liquid, which has a delightful mixed flavor. She drinks it all and instantly shrinks to ten inches high. Excited, she realizes she's now the right size for the garden door, but then remembers she left the golden key on the table, which she can no longer reach. She tries to climb the slippery table leg in vain and sits down to cry.

Soon, Alice spots a small glass box under the table, containing a tiny cake marked "EAT ME" in currants. She decides to eat it, reasoning that if she grows larger, she can reach the key, and if smaller, she can creep under the door. She eats a bit but remains the same size, which she finds "dull." She finishes the cake.

Instead of shrinking, Alice begins to grow enormously, exclaiming "Curiouser and curiouser!" Her feet become almost out of sight, and her head hits the ceiling, making her over nine feet tall. She manages to take the golden key and hurry to the garden door, but can only lie down and look into the garden with one eye. Overwhelmed, she begins to cry again, shedding so many tears that a large pool forms around her, four inches deep and reaching halfway down the hall.

She then hears the White Rabbit returning, now splendidly dressed and carrying white kid gloves and a fan. He mutters about the "Duchess" and being late. Alice timidly asks him for help, startling the Rabbit, who drops his gloves and fan and scurries away. Alice picks up the items and fans herself, feeling hot. She questions her identity, tries to recite lessons incorrectly, and concludes she must have been changed. She notices she's put on one of the Rabbit's gloves and is shrinking rapidly. She realizes the fan is the cause and drops it just in time, preventing her from shrinking out of existence. Now about two feet high, she finds the garden door shut and the key still on the unreachable table, feeling worse than ever.

Her foot slips, and she falls into the pool of tears she created, now up to her chin in salt water. She swims, wishing she hadn't cried so much, and encounters a **Mouse**. She tries to converse with it, first in English, then in French ("Où est ma chatte?"), which frightens the Mouse. Alice apologizes, realizing the Mouse dislikes cats. She tries to soothe it by talking about her pet cat Dinah, inadvertently praising Dinah's mouse-catching skills, which further offends the Mouse. She apologizes again and promises not to mention cats or dogs. The Mouse agrees to tell her its history if they reach the shore. The pool is now crowded with other creatures, including a **Duck**, a **Dodo**, a **Lory**, and an **Eaglet**. Alice leads them all to the bank.

On the bank, the wet, bedraggled group discusses how to get dry. The Mouse, assuming authority, begins to recite a dull historical text about William the Conqueror. The other animals interrupt with complaints. Alice, still wet, suggests the story isn't helping. The Dodo then proposes a "Caucus-race" as the most energetic remedy. It marks a circular course, and everyone runs when they like and stops when they like. After about half an hour, when they are all dry, the Dodo declares the race over and states, "Everybody has won, and all must have prizes." The Dodo appoints Alice to give out prizes. Alice finds a box of comfits in her pocket and distributes one to each creature. For her own prize, the Dodo takes a thimble from Alice's pocket and solemnly presents it back to her.

After eating the comfits, the group asks the Mouse to tell its promised history, specifically why it hates "C and D" (cats and dogs). The Mouse begins a "long and sad tale," but Alice, distracted by the text's tail-like shape on the page, keeps interrupting, misunderstanding the Mouse's words. The Mouse becomes very angry and walks away. Alice tries to call it back, and the other animals join in, but the Mouse refuses. Alice then mentions her cat Dinah, praising her hunting abilities, which causes all the birds to flee in alarm, leaving Alice alone and feeling lonely. She then hears footsteps, hoping it's the Mouse returning.

It is the White Rabbit, returning and frantically searching for his lost gloves and fan, muttering about the Duchess. Alice realizes he's looking for the items she picked up, but the great hall has vanished. The Rabbit mistakes Alice for his housemaid, **Mary Ann**, and imperiously orders her to run home and fetch a new pair of gloves and a fan. Frightened, Alice obeys and finds the Rabbit's house, marked "W. RABBIT." Inside, she finds a fan and some tiny white kid gloves. She then spots a bottle, drinks from it, hoping to grow larger again, and rapidly expands until she is stuck in the room, her elbow pressed against the door, and one foot up the chimney.

The Rabbit arrives, demanding Mary Ann open the door, but Alice's elbow blocks it. He decides to enter through the window. Alice, stretching out her hand, causes a shriek and broken glass, making her think the Rabbit fell into a cucumber-frame. She then hears the Rabbit angrily calling for "Pat" and another voice confirming his presence, digging for apples. Pat identifies Alice's arm filling the window. Alice again stretches her hand out, causing more shrieks and broken glass. She then hears voices planning to use ladders to get "Bill" down the chimney. Alice realizes Bill is a small animal. When Bill scratches in the chimney, Alice gives a sharp kick with her foot. She hears a chorus of "There goes Bill!" and then Bill's feeble squeaking voice describing being launched like a "Jack-in-the-box." The Rabbit suggests burning the house down, but Alice threatens to set her cat Dinah on them, causing silence. Pebbles then shower through the window, turning into little cakes on the floor. Alice eats one, hoping to shrink, and does so immediately.

Once small enough, Alice runs out of the house. Outside, she sees a crowd of animals and birds, with **Bill the Lizard** (the one from the chimney) being revived with a bottle by two guinea-pigs. The crowd rushes at Alice, but she flees into a thick wood. Her goals are to grow back to her normal size and find the beautiful garden. She encounters an enormous **Puppy**, which frightens her. She distracts it with a stick and eventually escapes. Resting, she remembers she still needs to grow and wonders what to eat. She finds a large mushroom and, peeping over its edge, sees a large blue **Caterpillar** sitting on top, smoking a hookah.

The Caterpillar asks Alice, "Who are _you?_" Alice explains she hardly knows anymore due to her frequent size changes. The Caterpillar is unimpressed by her confusion. It asks her to recite "'_You are old, Father William_,'" but Alice's recitation is nonsensical and altered. The Caterpillar declares it "wrong from beginning to end." When asked what size she wants to be, Alice says she'd like to be a little larger than three inches, finding that height "wretched." The Caterpillar, which is exactly three inches high, takes offense. Before crawling away, it tells Alice that "One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you grow shorter"—referring to the mushroom.

Alice breaks off a piece of the mushroom from each side. Nibbling one piece, she shrinks rapidly until her chin touches her foot. She quickly eats from the other piece, and her head is freed, but her neck grows immensely long, like a serpent's, extending above a "sea of green leaves" (which turn out to be treetops). A large **Pigeon** flies into her face, screaming "Serpent!" The Pigeon explains its struggles to protect its eggs from serpents and mistakes Alice's long neck for one. Alice tries to explain she is a "little girl," but the Pigeon finds this unbelievable. Alice denies looking for eggs or liking them raw. The sulky Pigeon returns to its nest. Alice, remembering the mushroom pieces, carefully nibbles from each until she is back to her normal height. She then sees a little house and, realizing she's too large, eats some mushroom to shrink to nine inches high before approaching.

Alice arrives at the Duchess's house. She sees a **Fish-Footman** deliver a croquet invitation from the Queen to a **Frog-Footman**. Alice finds their formal, repetitive exchange amusing. After the Fish-Footman departs, Alice tries to enter. The Frog-Footman, speaking nonsensically, explains that knocking is useless due to the noise inside and his position on the same side of the door. A plate then flies out of the house, narrowly missing the Footman's head. Frustrated, Alice opens the door and enters a smoke-filled kitchen. The **Duchess** is nursing a constantly sneezing and howling baby, while the **Cook** stirs a peppery soup and throws kitchenware at them. A **Cheshire Cat** sits grinning by the fire.

Alice asks the Duchess why her cat grins, learning it's a "Cheshire cat." The Cook resumes throwing things, narrowly missing the baby's nose. The Duchess offers Alice convoluted "morals" for everything. Alice tries to share her knowledge of the earth's rotation, but the Duchess interrupts with "chop off her head!" The Duchess then sings a violent lullaby to the baby, shaking it, and then flings the squirming baby at Alice, telling her to nurse it while she goes to play croquet with the Queen. Alice, struggling to hold the baby, takes it outside. She notices its pig-like features and realizes it has completely transformed into a pig. She sets it down, and it trots away into the wood.

Alice then sees the Cheshire Cat again, sitting on a tree bough. She asks it for directions. The Cat explains that where she goes depends on where she wants to get to. It then informs her that everyone here is mad, including the **Hatter** and the **March Hare**, and even Alice herself, simply for being there. The Cat explains its own madness by noting it growls when pleased and wags its tail when angry. The Cat vanishes and reappears several times, confirming the baby turned into a pig. Its final disappearance leaves only its grin floating in the air for a moment, which Alice finds "the most curious thing." Alice then heads towards the March Hare's house, shrinking herself before approaching.

At the March Hare's house, Alice finds the **March Hare** and the **Hatter** having a perpetual tea-party under a tree, using a sleeping **Dormouse** as a cushion. They rudely tell her there's no room, but Alice sits down. The March Hare offers non-existent wine, and the Hatter makes personal remarks about her hair. The Hatter then poses a riddle, "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?", which no one, including himself or the March Hare, knows the answer to. They engage in a nonsensical discussion about language and time. The Hatter explains that he and "Time" (personified) had a quarrel after he sang at the Queen of Hearts' concert, resulting in it always being six o'clock (tea-time) for them. They continually move around the table as dishes get used.

When asked to tell a story, Alice declines, so the Dormouse is pinched awake to tell one. The Dormouse begins a story about three little sisters who lived in a "treacle-well" and learned to draw "treacle." Alice's questions about this puzzling tale lead to more arguments and interruptions from the Hatter and March Hare. The Hatter calls for a clean cup, and they all shift places, leaving Alice worse off. The Dormouse eventually drifts back to sleep, listing things that begin with "M." Alice, disgusted by their rudeness and the nonsensical conversation, walks away, vowing never to return. She then notices a door in a tree, enters it, and finds herself back in the long hall. Taking the golden key, she uses her remaining mushroom piece to shrink to a foot high and finally enters the beautiful garden.

In the garden, Alice sees three card-shaped gardeners (Two, Five, and Seven) busily painting white roses red. She overhears them explaining they planted the wrong color rose and will be beheaded by the Queen if discovered. Suddenly, "The Queen! The Queen!" is announced, and the gardeners flatten themselves on their faces. A grand procession arrives: soldiers, courtiers, royal children, and guests (including the White Rabbit and the **Knave of Hearts**), followed by the **King and Queen of Hearts**. Alice remains standing. The Queen sternly asks her name and then demands to know who the prostrate gardeners are. Alice, surprisingly bold, says she doesn't know. The furious Queen screams, "Off with her head!" but Alice loudly replies, "Nonsense!" silencing the Queen.

The King timidly intervenes, calling Alice "only a child." The Queen orders the Knave to turn the gardeners over. She then demands to know what they've been doing and, upon hearing their explanation, again shouts, "Off with their heads!" Alice quickly hides the gardeners in a large flower-pot, and the soldiers sent to execute them cannot find them. The Queen then asks Alice if she can play croquet.

The croquet game is chaotic: the ground is ridged, the balls are live hedgehogs, the mallets are live flamingoes, and the arches are doubled-up soldiers who constantly walk away. Alice struggles to control her flamingo. The Queen frequently screams "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" at other players. Alice, feeling uneasy, then sees the grinning **Cheshire Cat**'s head appear in the air. She complains to it about the unfair game. The King approaches, curious about the Cat's head, and Alice introduces it. The King, disliking its look, orders its removal. The Queen decrees, "Off with his head!" and the King goes to fetch the executioner.

Alice finds her hedgehog gone and retrieves her flamingo. She returns to find the King, Queen, and executioner arguing about how to behead a head without a body (as only the Cat's head is visible). Alice suggests they ask the Duchess, who is in prison. The Queen sends the executioner to fetch the Duchess. As the executioner leaves, the Cat's head begins to fade and completely disappears by the time the executioner returns with the Duchess. The King and executioner frantically search for the vanished head while the others return to the game.

The **Duchess** affectionately links arms with Alice, now in a much pleasanter mood, attributing her earlier savagery to pepper. She continues to share morals on various topics. Alice finds her chin uncomfortable. The Queen then reappears, furious at seeing the Duchess, and threatens her with execution. The Duchess vanishes instantly. The Queen returns to the game, ordering more executions. Eventually, all players except the King, Queen, and Alice are in custody. The Queen, out of breath, asks Alice if she's seen the **Mock Turtle**. Alice says no, so the Queen sends her with a **Gryphon** (found sleeping) to hear the Mock Turtle's history. As they leave, Alice hears the King pardon all the imprisoned players.

The Gryphon reveals that the Queen never actually executes anyone; it's "all her fancy." They find the **Mock Turtle** sitting sadly on a rock, sighing. The Gryphon again says the Mock Turtle's sorrow is "all his fancy." The Mock Turtle, in a deep, hollow tone, agrees to tell his history. He begins by saying he was "a real Turtle." Alice's interruption about him being called "Tortoise" (because he taught them) irritates him. He describes his sea-school education, including "Reeling and Writhing" and "Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision." Alice is unfamiliar with "Uglification." He also learned "Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography," and "Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils" from a conger-eel. The Gryphon adds that he went to a "Classics master," an old crab who taught "Laughing and Grief." The Mock Turtle explains that lessons "lessen from day to day" (ten hours the first, nine the next, etc.).

The Gryphon cuts off the lesson discussion, telling the Mock Turtle to talk about games. The Mock Turtle, after deep sobs, describes the "Lobster Quadrille" dance, involving lobsters as partners, throwing them out to sea, and turning somersaults. He and the Gryphon demonstrate the dance around Alice while the Mock Turtle sings "Will you walk a little faster?" a song about a whiting and a snail. Alice enjoys the song. The Mock Turtle explains that whitings have their tails in their mouths because they were thrown far out to sea. The Gryphon adds that whitings "do the boots and shoes" under the sea, which are made of "Soles and eels." Alice then begins to tell her own adventures, starting from seeing the White Rabbit. When she recounts her incorrect recitation of "Father William" to the Caterpillar, the Mock Turtle and Gryphon find it very curious. The Gryphon makes her recite "'_’Tis the voice of the sluggard_'," but Alice's version is again nonsensical, about a lobster. She then tries another verse, "I passed by his garden..." but the Mock Turtle interrupts, demanding an explanation. The Gryphon tells Alice to stop. The Gryphon then asks if they want another dance figure or a song from the Mock Turtle. Alice eagerly chooses a song. The Mock Turtle, sobbing, sings "Beautiful Soup." As he begins to repeat the chorus, a cry of "The trial’s beginning!" is heard in the distance. The Gryphon grabs Alice's hand and hurries her off to the trial.

Alice and the Gryphon arrive at the court, finding the King and Queen of Hearts on their throne, surrounded by various creatures and cards. The Knave of Hearts is in chains, accused of stealing tarts. The White Rabbit is the Herald. Alice notes the King is the judge (wearing his crown over a wig), and twelve creatures are the jurymen, busily writing on slates (writing their names, then "stupid things!" when Alice says it). Alice removes Bill the Lizard's squeaking pencil. The White Rabbit reads the accusation: "The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts... The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts..."

The first witness is the **Hatter**, who arrives with a teacup and bread-and-butter. He gives confused testimony about when he started tea and "twinkling" things, contradicting the March Hare and Dormouse. Alice begins to grow larger again, making the Dormouse complain. The King, growing impatient and threatening execution, demands clear evidence. The Hatter's testimony remains nonsensical. A guinea-pig cheers and is "suppressed" by being put into a canvas bag. The Hatter is dismissed, and the Queen orders his head off, but he escapes. The next witness is the **Duchess's Cook**, carrying a pepper-box. She refuses to give evidence. The King, cross-examining, asks what tarts are made of. The Cook says "Pepper, mostly," and the Dormouse (from behind) adds "Treacle." The Queen, enraged, orders the Dormouse beheaded, and in the ensuing confusion, the Cook disappears.

Finally, the White Rabbit calls the last witness: **Alice**. Alice, forgetting her immense size, jumps up and knocks over the jury-box, scattering the jurymen. She quickly puts them back, including Bill the Lizard who she initially put in upside down. The King asks Alice what she knows about the business. Alice replies, "Nothing whatever." The King attempts to declare this "important," but the White Rabbit corrects him to "unimportant." The King then reads "Rule Forty-two: _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_." Everyone looks at Alice, who is now very large. Alice denies being a mile high and argues the rule was just invented. The King, flustered, tells the jury to consider their verdict.

The White Rabbit then announces new evidence: a paper just picked up, containing a set of verses, not in the prisoner's handwriting. The King insists it proves the Knave's guilt, but Alice loudly disagrees, stating they don't even know what the verses mean. The King orders the White Rabbit to read the nonsensical verses. The King tries to interpret the verses as evidence against the Knave, even finding a pun. The Queen demands "Sentence first—verdict afterwards!" Alice vehemently protests, calling it "Stuff and nonsense!" The Queen, turning purple, screams, "Off with her head!" But Alice, having grown to her full size, declares, "Who cares for you? You're nothing but a pack of cards!"

At this, the entire pack of cards flies up into the air and rains down upon her. Alice screams and tries to beat them off. Suddenly, she finds herself lying on the riverbank, her head in her sister's lap. Her sister gently brushes away leaves and tells her to wake up from her long sleep. Alice exclaims about her "curious dream" and recounts all her strange adventures to her sister. Her sister listens, then sends Alice off for tea. Alice runs off, still thinking about her wonderful dream.

Alice's sister remains on the bank, dreaming of Alice's adventures, recalling the White Rabbit, the frightened Mouse, the tea-party, the Queen's commands, the pig-baby, the Gryphon, the Lizard's slate-pencil, the suppressed guinea-pigs, and the Mock Turtle's sobs. She imagines these fantastical sounds transforming back into the ordinary sounds of nature and a farm-yard. Finally, she pictures Alice as a grown woman, preserving the loving heart of her childhood, and sharing these strange tales of Wonderland with other children, evoking in them the same wonder and joy.

The story begins in the Oblonsky household in Moscow, where Darya Alexandrovna, known as Dolly, has discovered her husband, Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky (Stiva), is having an affair with their French governess. This revelation has thrown the family into disarray, with Dolly refusing to live with Stiva and the household staff in confusion. Stiva, while acknowledging his fault, struggles with genuine remorse, attributing Dolly's extreme reaction to his "idiotic smile" when confronted. He believes his wife, being older and less attractive, should have been more indulgent.

Stiva learns via telegram that his sister, Anna Arkadyevna Karenina, is coming from Petersburg. He and his valet, Matvey, hope Anna's arrival will facilitate a reconciliation with Dolly. Dolly, however, initially refuses to see Anna.

Meanwhile, Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin, an old childhood friend of Stiva and the Shtcherbatsky family, arrives in Moscow with the firm intention of proposing to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, Dolly's younger sister. Levin is deeply in love with Kitty, viewing her as a perfect, almost unearthly being, and feeling himself unworthy and lacking a definitive social standing compared to his peers. He had previously left Moscow after an earlier attempt at courtship, convinced it was impossible, but now returns resolved.

At the Zoological Gardens, where Kitty is skating, Levin approaches her. Their interaction is charged with emotion. Kitty, initially warm, becomes reserved when Levin, flustered, hints at his deeper feelings. Soon after, Vronsky, a charming and wealthy officer, arrives. Kitty's eyes brighten noticeably when she sees him, confirming Levin's fears that she loves Vronsky. Levin, seeing this, is heartbroken and leaves abruptly.

That evening, Kitty tells her mother about Levin's proposal and her refusal, believing she acted correctly. She feels pity for Levin but is also happy, yet her happiness is "poisoned by doubts" because she remembers Vronsky. Upstairs, the Prince and Princess argue about Kitty's suitors. The Prince strongly favors Levin, criticizing Vronsky as a mere "peacock" who is only "amusing himself" and blaming his wife for "disgracing" their daughter with her matchmaking. The Princess, however, favors Vronsky for his wealth and social standing, though she secretly worries he might not have serious intentions.

Vronsky, unaware of the Shtcherbatskys' domestic turmoil, feels a strong "spiritual bond" with Kitty. He dismisses marriage as "ridiculous" but is delighted by Kitty's affection.

Anna arrives in Moscow and, through her compassionate and direct approach, successfully mediates a reconciliation between Dolly and Stiva. Dolly, initially bitter about Stiva's infidelity and her own "humiliating" position, is moved by Anna's genuine sympathy and argument that Stiva's home and wife are "sacred" to him, and his lapse was "not an infidelity of the heart." Dolly confesses her enduring love for Stiva and accepts Anna's advice to forgive him completely.

At a ball later, Kitty is entranced by Vronsky. She observes Anna and Vronsky dancing, and sees Anna's intoxicating effect on Vronsky, while also noticing Vronsky's "humble submission and dread" in Anna's presence. Kitty realizes her "unhappiness was complete," confirming Vronsky's love is directed elsewhere. Anna, too, feels the growing intensity of her connection with Vronsky, which leaves her agitated and excited.

Levin, in Moscow, visits his sick brother Nikolay, who is dying of consumption. Nikolay is emaciated and irritable, struggling with his past and his current life with Marya Nikolaevna, a woman he lives with but has "got rid of" due to her "horrid" nature, only to return to her. Levin is deeply distressed by his brother's condition and confronts his own mortality and lack of purpose. Nikolay, despite his illness, maintains his cynical views on society and human endeavor.

Kitty, heartbroken and unwell after the ball, goes abroad with her family to a German watering-place. She is drawn to Varenka, a serene and philanthropic Russian woman, and attempts to emulate her spiritual, altruistic lifestyle, finding temporary solace. However, this new path is disrupted when a sick artist, Petrov, to whom Kitty offers help, develops an inappropriate attachment, causing discomfort. Her father, the Prince, also returns, his down-to-earth perspective and jests disrupt Kitty's idealized view of her new friends. She realizes the superficiality of some of the piety she admired and the underlying self-interest in people.

Back in Petersburg, Anna's affair with Vronsky deepens. After a horse race where Vronsky is injured, Anna, in a moment of intense emotion, confesses her infidelity to Alexey Alexandrovitch. He is enraged, deciding to divorce her and take their son, Seryozha. He consults a lawyer, but his religious scruples and desire to avoid public scandal lead him to decide against a formal divorce. Instead, he insists on maintaining an "external _status quo_," demanding Anna cease all contact with Vronsky and observe social proprieties, implicitly to punish her.

Anna falls gravely ill after childbirth (delivering a daughter, who is Vronsky's child). Alexey Alexandrovitch, believing her to be dying, is overcome with Christian forgiveness and pity for her, and for Vronsky, who had attempted suicide in despair. This experience brings Alexey Alexandrovitch a profound sense of spiritual peace. He agrees to Anna's request for a divorce. He also develops a tender affection for the newborn baby, despite knowing it is not his.

However, Anna does not die. Recovered, she finds herself isolated in Petersburg society, shunned by former friends except Princess Betsy, and longs to see her son, Seryozha, whom Alexey Alexandrovitch now forbids her to see. Countess Lidia Ivanovna, Alexey Alexandrovitch's pious confidante, takes over the management of his household and Seryozha's education, actively working to keep Anna separated from her son. Anna makes a desperate, secret visit to Seryozha on his birthday, which is a tender but painful reunion, ending in his distress and her swift departure before Alexey Alexandrovitch discovers her presence.

Levin, after his initial rejection and a period of despair and intellectual searching, experiences a spiritual awakening during a night spent on a haycock. He questions his reliance on reason and intellectual pursuits, realizing that true meaning and goodness come from an intuitive faith and a simple, laborious life connected to the land and the people. He reconciles with Kitty, who confirms her love for him through a playful exchange of chalked initials. They marry.

After their wedding, Levin and Kitty return to his country estate. Their initial married life is marked by unexpected quarrels stemming from their adjustments to each other and from Levin's lingering jealousy and perfectionism. However, they soon settle into a comfortable rhythm. Kitty, now pregnant, embraces her role as mistress of the house, enjoying domestic duties and showing a new strength of character. Levin dedicates himself to his agricultural reforms, finding purpose in his work and a profound, if sometimes complicated, love for his wife.

Anna and Vronsky, meanwhile, are living together in Moscow, waiting for Alexey Alexandrovitch to grant the divorce. Anna grows increasingly jealous and irritable, feeling Vronsky's love waning and her social position as a fallen woman unbearable. Vronsky, feeling stifled by her demands and her situation, becomes cold and distant. Their relationship is strained by constant conflict. Anna, haunted by the memory of a prophetic nightmare, begins to contemplate suicide as the only escape from her misery and a way to punish Vronsky.

One evening, after a particularly bitter quarrel, Anna sends Vronsky a note begging him to return, but he, angered by her "threats" and her refusal to understand his need for independence, goes out instead. Anna, filled with despair and a desire for revenge, sees Vronsky with Princess Sorokina, confirming her fears of his indifference. She decides to go to the railway station.

At the station, as she awaits the train, Anna is overwhelmed by a rush of memories and self-reproach. She recalls the man crushed by a train on the day she first met Vronsky, and a sudden, terrible clarity descends upon her: death is the only escape. Despite a fleeting resurgence of joyful childhood memories, she fixates on the wheels of an approaching train. She drops her red bag and throws herself under the second carriage, dying instantly.

Two months later, Sergey Ivanovitch learns of Anna's death. He and Katavasov are at a train station, witnessing a crowd of volunteers departing for the Servian War. Sergey Ivanovitch finds the public's enthusiasm for the war a "manifestation of public opinion," a new purpose. Vronsky is also at the station, looking aged and worn, on his way to Servia with a squadron he has raised at his own expense. He is consumed by grief and guilt over Anna's death, which he sees as his fault. He views life as worthless and welcomes the war as a means to "meet death."

Levin, now a father to a son named Mitya, continues his life in the country. He grapples with his faith and the meaning of life, realizing that intellectual reasoning alone cannot provide answers. He finds profound spiritual peace in the simple truths of Christianity and in his love for his family, despite the ongoing challenges and his own imperfections. He embraces his life, finding meaning in "the positive meaning of goodness" he has the power to put into it.

Raskolnikov, a young, impoverished former student living in a cramped garret in S. Place, is deeply in debt to his landlady. On a hot July evening, he leaves his lodging, avoiding his landlady. He mutters to himself about attempting a significant, unstated "thing" and expresses frustration at minor fears, like his conspicuous hat, which he believes could compromise his "plan." He walks slowly towards a large house, counting the 730 steps, feeling a growing excitement for a "rehearsal" of his "project."

He enters the large house, where he knows only an old woman lives on the fourth floor. He rings her bell, and she, Alyona Ivanovna, a small, withered, suspicious pawnbroker, opens the door. Raskolnikov, introducing himself as a student, offers to pawn an old silver watch. The old woman, remembering his previous visit, offers a paltry price, deducting interest from a previous pledge. Raskolnikov is angered but accepts, noting her keys and suspecting a strong-box. He receives a small sum. As he leaves, he casually asks if her sister, Lizaveta, is always home. He then experiences intense repulsion for his plan, dismissing it as "nonsense."

Seeking distraction, Raskolnikov enters a tavern. He meets Marmeladov, a drunken, retired titular counsellor, who launches into a long, self-pitying confession. Marmeladov describes his educated wife, Katerina Ivanovna, who is consumptive and works tirelessly for their three starving children. He admits to stealing his wife's money for drink and to having just taken the last 30 copecks from his daughter, Sonia, who supports the family through prostitution. Marmeladov delivers a dramatic speech about suffering and divine forgiveness for Sonia. He asks Raskolnikov to escort him home.

At Marmeladov's squalid lodging, Katerina Ivanovna confronts her husband, violently searching him for money. Finding none, she drags him by his hair, accusing him of squandering their last cent while the children starve. Raskolnikov, unseen, leaves a few coppers on the windowsill before departing, but later regrets it, thinking Sonia will need money for "smartness." He questions his own morality.

The next day, Raskolnikov awakens ill and irritable. His landlady, Praskovya Pavlovna, threatens to report him to the police for unpaid rent. He receives a letter from his mother, detailing his sister Dounia's ordeal as a governess. Dounia was harassed by her employer, Mr. Svidrigaïlov, who made improper advances. His wife, Marfa Petrovna, mistakenly blamed Dounia and publicly disgraced her, only to later clear her name upon discovering Dounia's letter rejecting Svidrigaïlov. Dounia is now engaged to Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin, a wealthy, practical man, who seeks a poor wife he can control. His mother and Dounia are coming to Petersburg, hoping Luzhin will help Raskolnikov's career.

Raskolnikov is enraged by the letter, seeing Dounia's marriage as a sacrifice for his benefit. He vows to prevent it, realizing his own poverty prevents him from offering an alternative. He wanders outside, observing a young, drunken girl being preyed upon by a dandy. He intervenes, giving a policeman money to help her, but then, in a sudden fit of apathy, tells the policeman to "let them be." He reflects on the "percentage" of society destined for ruin. He has a vivid dream of a peasant cruelly beating a weak horse to death. This dream sickens him, making him renounce his murderous "accursed dream." However, he then overhears Lizaveta Ivanovna discussing with a huckster that she will be out at seven o'clock the next day. This unexpected information rekindles his resolve, as it provides a perfect opportunity for his plan to murder Alyona Ivanovna.

He meticulously prepares a fake pledge (a piece of wood with iron) and a concealed noose for an axe in his coat. He almost gives up, but a chance discovery of an axe in the porter's empty room solidifies his intent. He goes to Alyona Ivanovna's flat. She lets him in, still suspicious. He strikes her head with the blunt side of the axe, then repeatedly, until she is dead. He then discovers Lizaveta Ivanovna, unexpectedly returning, staring in horror at her murdered sister. In a panic, Raskolnikov strikes Lizaveta with the sharp edge of the axe, killing her instantly. Overwhelmed by fear and loathing, he cleans the axe and his hands. He hides the stolen money and jewels from a box under a stone in a deserted yard.

A summons to the police station for his unpaid IOU causes him immense anxiety, as he fears they know about the murder. At the police station, the discussion of the pawnbroker murder (specifically the open door and the suspects, Koch and Pestryakov, being ruled out in favor of a painter named Nikolay) greatly agitates him. He faints. When he recovers, he provocatively taunts the head clerk, Zametov, with hints of his own involvement in the murder, describing how he would have hidden the stolen goods. Zametov is visibly unnerved. Raskolnikov's mother and Dounia arrive in Petersburg and come to his lodging, finding him in a fever. He demands Dounia break off her engagement to Luzhin, calling it a sacrifice for his sake. During this agitated conversation, Raskolnikov again collapses in a faint.

Razumihin, who has become fond of Dounia, takes charge, arranging for Zossimov (the doctor) to care for Raskolnikov and for Dounia and her mother to stay at Bakaleyev's, a nearby lodging. Razumihin reveals to Zossimov that Raskolnikov's "fixed idea" about the murder might be linked to his illness and a suspicion from the police.

At Raskolnikov's room, Luzhin arrives for his meeting with Dounia. Raskolnikov, despite his weakness, vehemently exposes Luzhin's mercenary motives for marrying Dounia and his slanderous accusations against Sonia. Dounia, now fully aware of Luzhin's character, breaks off the engagement and demands he leave. Luzhin, furious, blames Raskolnikov.

Shortly after, Sonia comes to Raskolnikov's room, inviting him to her father's funeral. Raskolnikov, in a feverish state, confesses to Sonia that he murdered Alyona Ivanovna and Lizaveta, explaining his theory of "extraordinary" men having the right to transgress moral laws. He confesses his motive was to test his own strength and determine if he was an "extraordinary man" like Napoleon. Sonia is horrified but expresses profound pity and love, urging him to confess publicly to find God and new life. Unknown to them, Svidrigaïlov has been listening to their entire conversation through a crack in the wall from the adjacent empty room.

Katerina Ivanovna's mental state rapidly deteriorates after her husband's death. She takes her children, dressed in makeshift costumes, into the street to beg, attempting to garner sympathy by highlighting their "genteel" background. She collapses, spitting blood, and is carried to Sonia's room, where she dies. Svidrigaïlov then reveals to Raskolnikov that he has made provisions for Katerina Ivanovna's children, settling money on them and arranging for their placement in institutions, effectively using the 10,000 roubles he had offered Dounia. He casually mentions he overheard Raskolnikov's confession to Sonia, confirming his knowledge of the murder.

Raskolnikov, overwhelmed, confronts Svidrigaïlov, warning him to abandon any designs on Dounia. Svidrigaïlov, cynical and depraved, recounts his own past, including his dead wife Marfa Petrovna's ghostly visitations and his plans to marry a 16-year-old girl. He also describes another young girl he "befriended." Dounia, arriving to confront Svidrigaïlov (due to a letter from him hinting at Raskolnikov's secret), is lured to his room. He confesses to having listened to Raskolnikov's confession to Sonia. He tries to coerce Dounia, declaring his love and offering to save Raskolnikov if she yields to him. Dounia pulls out a revolver and shoots at him, grazing his head. After a second misfire, she throws the weapon away. Svidrigaïlov, realizing she will never love him, gives her the key to the locked door and lets her go. He spends his final hours in taverns and then a squalid hotel, experiencing disturbing nightmares. At dawn, Svidrigaïlov goes to a public place by the Little Neva, gives a cryptic message to a guard, and shoots himself in the head.

Raskolnikov, after a final, tender conversation with his mother, who intuitively senses his great sorrow, and Dounia, who understands his guilt through Razumihin, makes his way to the police station. He hesitates, but driven by a strange compulsion, he goes to the Hay Market, where he bows down and kisses the earth, recalling Sonia's words. He then proceeds to the police station. He finds Ilya Petrovitch and, with white lips, confesses: "It was I killed the old pawnbroker woman and her sister Lizaveta with an axe and robbed them."

**Epilogue:**
Raskolnikov is confined to a Siberian prison for eight years of penal servitude. His trial reveals his full, clear confession, including the detail of the fake pledge and hiding the valuables under a stone without using them. Psychologists argue for temporary mental derangement, which, along with extenuating circumstances (his prior charity, rescuing children from a fire), leads to a more lenient sentence.

His mother falls ill during the trial and dies of brain fever, having suspected a terrible secret about her son. Dounia marries Razumihin. They plan to eventually move to Siberia to be near Raskolnikov. Sonia, using the money from Svidrigaïlov, follows Raskolnikov to Siberia. Raskolnikov initially remains sullen and indifferent in prison, feeling no true repentance, only wounded pride and shame at his "blunder." He believes his theory of extraordinary men was right, only that he failed. He endures a horrifying dream of a plague of madness afflicting the world.

Eventually, as he recovers from illness, he sees Sonia at the prison gate. Overwhelmed by her unwavering love and presence, he falls to her feet, weeping. This moment marks a profound turning point, a realization of his love for her and a softening of his heart. He finds renewal through love, feeling a new life beginning. The story concludes with the promise of his "gradual renewal" and "regeneration."

On a spring afternoon in Munich, Gustav Aschenbach, a renowned writer, takes a long walk after a demanding morning of work, feeling overwrought and unable to find rest. He observes an unusually dressed, red-haired man at a cemetery tram station, whose militant stare makes Aschenbach uncomfortable. This encounter unexpectedly sparks in Aschenbach an intense, youthful longing for travel, a desire to escape his disciplined, solitary life and its "coldly passionate service." He fantasizes about exotic, tropical landscapes and decides to take a three-to-four-week trip to a southern resort.

Aschenbach is a celebrated author, ennobled on his fiftieth birthday, known for his rigorous, disciplined approach to art, which he views as a "destructive battle." Despite not being robust, he had cultivated a dignified, formal style, moving away from youthful skepticism. His personal life saw the early death of his wife, leaving him with a married daughter but no son. His artistic life has left deep marks on his aging, tired face.

Two weeks later, Aschenbach departs for Trieste, then Pola, seeking a foreign destination. He stops at an Adriatic island but finds it dissatisfying due to bad weather and the lack of a sandy beach. Feeling a persistent internal disturbance, he abruptly decides to leave for Venice. On the ship to Venice, he encounters a theatrical ticket-seller and observes a group of young revelers, among whom is an old man meticulously disguised as a youth with paint, a wig, and false teeth. Aschenbach is horrified and feels a dream-like distortion of reality. After an unpleasant meal with the drunken old fop, the ship arrives in Venice under dreary skies.

Upon disembarking, Aschenbach takes a gondola to reach the Lido, where he intends to stay by the sea. The gondolier, a brutal and insolent man, refuses to take him to the public steamer dock, insisting on rowing him directly to the Lido. Aschenbach feels helpless and suspects the gondolier is a criminal or trying to cheat him, yet a "poison of inertia" prevents him from resisting effectively. After a brief encounter with singing brigands, Aschenbach reaches the Lido. When he goes to get change for the gondolier, the man, who turns out to be unlicensed, vanishes without payment.

Aschenbach settles into a hotel on the Lido. That evening, he observes a Polish aristocratic family in the lobby: three severely dressed girls and their fourteen-year-old brother, Tadzio, whose "godlike beauty" reminds Aschenbach of Greek sculpture. Tadzio, with his honey-colored hair and serious expression, catches Aschenbach's eye.

The next day, the weather remains poor, and Aschenbach considers leaving, recalling a previous illness he suffered in Venice. However, at breakfast, Tadzio reappears, moving with captivating charm. Aschenbach is again struck by the boy's beauty, though he notices Tadzio's teeth are pale and brittle, suggesting he is sickly and may not live long—a thought that strangely gratifies Aschenbach. Despite his earlier intentions to leave, Aschenbach finds himself deciding to stay in Venice, captivated by Tadzio. He attempts to write on the beach, inspired by Tadzio, but finds himself distracted by the boy's presence and activities. He watches Tadzio playing with other children, especially a boy named Jaschu, who kisses him. Aschenbach deduces Tadzio's name and is deeply moved watching him emerge from the sea, a sight that evokes mythological images.

Later that afternoon, Aschenbach visits Venice, but the oppressive sultriness, foul smells, and crowds reaffirm his decision to leave. He makes plans to depart the following morning for another watering place. He regrets his decision during a restless night and at breakfast, but the hotel staff rush him, further solidifying his intention to leave. As he bids silent farewell to Tadzio, he feels a pang of regret. On the steamboat journey away from Venice, he is overcome with intense sorrow and realizes how deeply attached he is to the city, feeling it is now a forbidden place. However, at the train station, a clerical error results in his trunk being mistakenly sent to Como. Aschenbach is seized by "adventurous delight" at this mishap, which provides him with a pretext to return to the Lido hotel. He feels a sense of fate, relief, and even hilarity, realizing that Tadzio was the true reason he found it so hard to leave. Back in an identical room, he accepts his situation with a "spontaneous act of welcome."

Days turn into weeks of sunny weather. Aschenbach's will is relaxed, and he finds deep contentment at the Lido, spending hours watching Tadzio on the beach. He constantly observes and admires the boy's "godlike sculpture," associating his beauty with philosophical ideas about art and the spirit, envisioning him as a Hyacinth loved by gods. Tadzio's beauty becomes Aschenbach's artistic inspiration, and he works on a prose piece while observing the boy, feeling an "exhilaration." He attempts to approach Tadzio one morning but is overcome by physical and emotional turmoil, his heart pounding, and he retreats. He no longer wishes for "soberness," finding his "intoxication" too precious. He stops thinking about leaving, sends for more money, and watches Tadzio, ignoring the passing time. He awakens early, witnessing the sunrise in a mythical light, and whispers Tadzio's name. Tadzio seems to notice Aschenbach's attention, sometimes deliberately walking close to him and their glances meet. One evening, Tadzio smiles directly at Aschenbach, a captivating, "Narcissus" like smile, which drives Aschenbach into the darkness of the garden, where he whispers, "I love you!"

In his fourth week, Aschenbach notices fewer guests and overhears the barber mention a "plague." He investigates in Venice, detecting a "sweetish and drug-like" smell and seeing municipal warnings for gastric diseases—euphemisms for a concealed epidemic. He learns from newspapers that authorities are suppressing news of an Indian cholera outbreak in Venice to protect tourism. He feels a "dark contentment" and complicity in this secret, as it ensures Tadzio's continued presence. He begins to stalk Tadzio, following him through Venice's labyrinthine streets, enduring physical exhaustion and moral degradation, even hiring a gondola to pursue Tadzio's family. One night, he presses his head against Tadzio's room door, "in utter drunkenness."

Despite moments of alarm, Aschenbach rationalizes his behavior by connecting his passion to the "Eros" revered by ancient heroes. He continues seeking reliable news of the plague, eventually extracting the truth from an English travel clerk. The clerk confirms a severe cholera outbreak, with high fatality rates and a cover-up by authorities, leading to demoralization, crime, and poisoning of victims. Aschenbach is advised to leave immediately, but he whispers, "I will keep silent!" and decides to remain, finding a perverse "intoxication" in his "share in the facts and the guilt," seeing "advantages of chaos."

That night, Aschenbach has a terrifying dream of a pagan ritual, a wild bacchanal with frenzied dancing, lewdness, and sacrifice to a "foreign god." He feels his resistance crushed and his soul tastes "unchastity and fury of decay." He awakens shattered, openly disregarding others' suspicions as guests flee the emptying hotel. Tadzio and his family, however, remain. Aschenbach, now unconcerned with morality, begins to rejuvenate his appearance, dying his hair black, curling it, and applying cosmetics to his face to appear youthful. The barber tells him, "Now the gentleman can fall in love unhesitatingly."

A storm rises, filling the air with the smell of rotting things. Aschenbach, tracking Tadzio through the diseased city, feels the food is poisoned. Tadzio, aware of Aschenbach's pursuit, occasionally looks back, "not betraying him," alluring the lover. Aschenbach eventually loses sight of Tadzio in the winding alleys. Exhausted and feverish, he rests by a cistern, surrounded by the smell of carbolic acid. In a semi-conscious state, he reflects on the corrupted nature of the artist's path to beauty, concluding that it is a "perilous," "sinful" road leading to "intoxication and to desire," to the "precipice."

A few days later, feeling unwell with vertigo and malaise, Aschenbach learns that Tadzio's family is finally leaving after lunch. He goes to the deserted, dirty beach. He observes Tadzio and his few remaining companions. Jaschu, the stocky boy, violently wrestles Tadzio, pinning his face in the sand, nearly strangling him. Aschenbach is enraged but does not intervene. Tadzio, pale and disheveled, slowly walks to a sandbank in the sea. He stands there, a solitary figure against the mists, then turns and looks back at Aschenbach, seemingly smiling and nodding, "vaguely guiding towards egregious promises." Aschenbach, as if to follow, tries to stand up but collapses in his chair. Later that day, the world receives the news of his death.

The story begins in a village in La Mancha, where an unnamed gentleman, nearing fifty, lives a modest life with his housekeeper, his niece, and a farm lad. He owns a lance, a buckler, a lean hack, and a greyhound. This gentleman becomes consumed by reading books of chivalry, neglecting his property and field sports, and even selling land to acquire more of these books. He particularly admires the works of Feliciano de Silva. His obsession drives him to lose his wits, believing the fantastical events in these books to be true history. He frequently argues with his village curate and barber about the merits of various knights, concluding that he must become a knight-errant himself to revive the practice and bring renown to himself and his country.

His first steps involve cleaning his great-grandfather's rusty armor, making a makeshift closed helmet from pasteboard (which breaks on the first test, then is reinforced with iron). He spends four days naming his hack "Rocinante" to reflect its new, elevated status. He then names himself "Don Quixote," adding "of La Mancha" to honor his homeland. Finally, he decides he needs a lady love, choosing a local farm-girl named Aldonza Lorenzo, whom he renames "Dulcinea del Toboso."

One hot July morning, Don Quixote secretly sallies forth on Rocinante. A terrible thought strikes him: he hasn't been dubbed a knight. He resolves to be knighted by the first person he meets. He rides all day, imitating knightly speeches and addressing his imagined lady. Towards nightfall, he mistakes an inn for a castle. He sees two young women (local girls) at the door, imagining them as fair maidens, and a swineherd's horn blast as a dwarf's trumpet. He courteously addresses the "ladies," but his appearance and language make them laugh. The innkeeper, a fat man, emerges, amused but also awed by Don Quixote's full armor. Don Quixote addresses him as "Sir Castellan." He dismounts with difficulty and insists on special care for Rocinante. The girls help remove his breastplate, but he refuses to take off his makeshift helmet, which is tied on with ribbons. He eats a meager supper of stockfish (which he believes is trout), fed by one of the girls because his helmet prevents him from eating himself. A sowgelder's pipe convinces him he is being entertained with music. He remains distressed that he is not yet a dubbed knight.

That night, Don Quixote kneels before the innkeeper in the stable, demanding to be dubbed a knight the next morning, after watching his arms. The innkeeper, realizing his guest is mad, decides to humor him. He explains there's no chapel, so the courtyard will do. He also advises Don Quixote that knights-errant, though not usually written about, always carry money, clean shirts, and ointments, and should have squires. Don Quixote promises to follow this advice. He places his armor on a trough by a well and begins his watch.

Later, a carrier tries to water his mules and moves Don Quixote's armor. Don Quixote warns him, then, invoking Dulcinea, strikes the carrier senseless with his lance. He resumes his watch. Another carrier approaches, and Don Quixote strikes him too, wounding him severely. An uproar ensues, with the carriers' comrades throwing stones at Don Quixote, who defends himself with his buckler. The innkeeper intervenes, explaining Don Quixote's madness. To get rid of him, the landlord performs a burlesque knighting ceremony using his account-book for prayers. One of the girls, La Tolosa, girds on his sword, and Don Quixote renames her Doña Tolosa. The other, La Molinera, buckles his spur, and he renames her Doña Molinera. Don Quixote, now a knight, thanks the host and rides off without paying.

Don Quixote, joyful in his new knighthood, remembers the advice about money and a squire. He decides to return home. The Castle of Dracula stands against the red sky.

**Chapter I**
The narrator introduces himself as Pip, a shortening of his Christian name Philip and his family name Pirrip. He is an orphan, having never known his parents, Philip and Georgiana Pirrip, who are buried in the local churchyard along with five of his infant brothers. Pip's earliest impressions of his parents are derived from their tombstones, imagining his father as a "square, stout, dark man, with curly black hair" and his mother as "freckled and sickly." He lives in the marsh country, near the river, about twenty miles from the sea, and is raised by his older sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, who is married to Joe Gargery, the blacksmith.

One raw afternoon, while Pip is visiting the churchyard, a fearful man emerges from among the graves. This man, a convict dressed in coarse grey with a great iron on his leg, threatens Pip with violence, demanding to know his name and where he lives. Pip, terrified, identifies himself and points towards his village. The convict then turns Pip upside down, emptying his pockets of a piece of bread, which he devours. He further threatens Pip, ordering him to bring a file and "wittles" (food) to him at the old Battery on the marshes early the next morning, or face dire consequences, specifically having his "heart and liver out." The convict adds to Pip's terror by claiming he is not alone, and that a "young man hid with me," who is even more dangerous, will find and harm Pip if he fails. Pip, in mortal fear, promises to comply. The convict releases him, limping towards the low church wall and then towards a distant gibbet. Pip, looking for the mysterious young man, sees no one and runs home.

**Chapter II**
Pip's sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, is described as more than twenty years older, not good-looking, and known for raising Pip "by hand," which in practice means she frequently hits both Pip and her husband Joe. She is tall, bony, has black hair and eyes, and a "prevailing redness of skin," and constantly wears a coarse apron "stuck full of pins and needles." Joe Gargery, the blacksmith, is a mild, good-natured, and somewhat foolish man.

He worries that revealing the truth would make Joe think him worse than he is and lead to a loss of Joe's confidence. Joe carries Pip home on his back. Mr. Wopsle, tired and ill-tempered, blames the expedition. Inside, Joe recounts the convict's confession, and the other visitors invent elaborate theories about how the convict entered the pantry, with Pumblechook's wild theory being accepted. Pip's sister takes him to bed. Pip's internal struggle with guilt and secrecy persists long after.

**Chapter VII**
Pip's early education is described, including his literal interpretations of tombstones and catechism lessons. He is to be apprenticed to Joe and works odd jobs for neighbors, with his earnings saved in a money-box. Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt keeps an evening school and a small shop, assisted by her granddaughter, Biddy, an orphan like Pip. Pip learns to read, write, and cipher with Biddy's help.

One winter night, a year after the marsh incident, Pip writes a simple letter to Joe on his slate. Joe, illiterate, is amazed by Pip's "scholarship." Joe then reveals his own childhood: his father was a violent drunkard who often beat his mother and him, preventing him from attending school. Joe worked as a blacksmith to support his father until his death, and later his mother. Feeling lonely, Joe married Pip's sister, assuring her he would take in "the poor little child" (Pip). Pip is deeply moved by Joe's kindness.

Joe explains that Mrs. Joe, who is "given to government" (controlling), would disapprove of his learning, fearing he might "rise" and become a "rebel." He speaks of her violent "Ram-page" fits. Pip feels a new admiration for Joe.

Later, Mrs. Joe and Uncle Pumblechook return from market, with Mrs. Joe excitedly announcing that "Miss Havisham, up town," wants Pip to go and play there. Pumblechook, who had recommended Pip, believes Pip's fortune will be made. Mrs. Joe subjects Pip to a thorough cleaning and dresses him in his uncomfortable best suit. Pumblechook gives Pip a lecture on gratitude. Pip leaves with Pumblechook in his chaise-cart, still uncertain about what he is meant to do at Miss Havisham's.

**Chapter VIII**
Pip spends the night at Mr. Pumblechook's, finding breakfast with him unpleasant due to his constant arithmetic questions and meager portions. At ten o'clock, they go to Miss Havisham's, an old, dismal, barred brick house with a disused brewery. A young lady, Estella, lets them in but prevents Pumblechook from entering, stating Miss Havisham does not wish to see him. Pumblechook, offended, departs with a final admonition for Pip to behave well.

Estella, scornful and acting much older than Pip, leads him through dark passages by candlelight. She tells him the house's other name is "Satis," meaning "enough," implying that its owner should want nothing else. She then leaves him alone in a large, candle-lit dressing-room, taking the candle with her. Pip, frightened, enters to find Miss Havisham.

Miss Havisham is an old lady dressed in faded, yellowing white bridal clothes, with white hair and bridal flowers. One shoe is on, the other on the table. Her watch and a clock in the room are stopped at twenty minutes to nine. Her figure is shrunken and withered. Pip is terrified, likening her to a waxwork and a skeleton. She asks Pip his name and why he has come, then tells him to come closer. She asks what he touches on her left side, and when he replies, "Your heart," she exclaims, "Broken!" with a weird smile.

Miss Havisham, stating she is tired and wants "diversion," commands Pip to "play." Pip, confused and fearing his sister's wrath, struggles to comply. After he admits he is sorry for her but cannot play, Miss Havisham calls for Estella. Estella, whom Pip recognizes as the young lady from the gate, is beautiful but proud. Miss Havisham tells Estella she can "break his heart" and instructs them to play cards. Estella mocks Pip's "coarse hands" and "thick boots," winning the game easily. Pip feels ashamed. Miss Havisham, observing, asks Pip what he thinks of Estella. He whispers that she is proud, pretty, and insulting, and he wants to go home. Miss Havisham sends him downstairs to eat and roam, telling him to return in six days.

Estella gives Pip bread, meat, and beer in a "dog-like" manner, humiliating him and making him cry in secret. He explores the deserted brewery and garden. He has a brief, terrifying hallucination of Miss Havisham hanging from a beam. Estella returns, taunting him for crying, then lets him out. Pip goes to Pumblechook's, leaves a message, and walks home, feeling ashamed of his common background and resolving to ask Joe why "knaves" are called "Jacks."

**Chapter IX**
Pip's sister subjects him to intense questioning about Miss Havisham's house, physically punishing him for his insufficient answers. Pip struggles to describe the strange reality of Satis House to his sister and Pumblechook, fearing they would not understand or would judge Miss Havisham and Estella. When Pumblechook arrives, demanding details, Pip invents an extravagant story: Miss Havisham sits in a black velvet coach in her room, served cake and wine on gold plates by Estella, and has immense dogs that fight for veal-cutlets. He adds details about flags and swords, and a cupboard with pistols, jam, and pills. Pumblechook, who has never seen Miss Havisham, corroborates the candle-lit room.

Joe is amazed by the story, but Mrs. Joe and Pumblechook speculate about Pip's future, assuming Miss Havisham will "do something" for him. Joe innocently suggests Pip might get one of the dogs, which Mrs. Joe dismisses angrily, sending him to work. Later, Pip, feeling immense guilt towards Joe, confesses that his stories were lies. Joe is shocked but calmly tells Pip that "lies is lies" and will not make him less common. Joe then tells Pip about his own abusive childhood with an alcoholic father, explaining how it prevented his education. He recalls marrying Pip's sister out of loneliness and his efforts to protect Pip. He reveals Mrs. Joe's controlling nature. Pip develops a new admiration for Joe.

Mrs. Joe and Pumblechook return from market, and Mrs. Joe excitedly announces that Miss Havisham wants Pip to "play" at her house. Pumblechook, having recommended Pip, believes Pip's fortune will be made. Pip endures a rigorous cleaning and is dressed in uncomfortable clothes. He leaves with Pumblechook, still confused about his role at Satis House.

**Chapter X**
Pip decides to improve himself by getting all of Biddy's knowledge. He describes the chaotic evening school run by Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt, where Biddy is the true teacher. Pip makes progress in reading, writing, and arithmetic.

One Saturday night, Pip goes to call Joe from the Three Jolly Bargemen pub. There, he finds Joe, Mr. Wopsle, and a stranger. The stranger, a "secret-looking man," pays for their rum and questions Joe about his blacksmithing and the earlier convict chase. He learns Pip was present. When stirring his rum, the stranger uses a file, which only Pip sees. Pip immediately recognizes it as Joe's file and realizes this man knows his convict. As Joe and Pip leave, the stranger gives Pip a shilling, folded in crumpled paper.

At home, Mrs. Joe discovers two one-pound notes inside the paper. Joe, in his honesty, rushes back to the pub to return them, but the stranger is gone. Mrs. Joe puts the notes away. Pip is haunted by the encounter, realizing he is entangled in a secret conspiracy with convicts.

**Chapter XI**
Pip returns to Miss Havisham's. Estella leads him to a gloomy room where he finds Miss Havisham's relatives: Camilla, Sarah Pocket, and Cousin Raymond. They are sycophantic and critical, discussing a deceased relative and the proper degree of mourning. Estella takes Pip aside and slaps him, mocking him for not crying. On the stairs, they encounter a "burly man" with a large head and suspicious eyes, who inspects Pip and warns him to "behave yourself." This man, whose hand smells of scented soap, is Mr. Jaggers.

In Miss Havisham's room, everything is unchanged. She sends Pip into a large, dusty room with a long table, a decayed bride-cake, and cobwebs. Miss Havisham enters, looking like a witch, and tells Pip he is to walk her around the room, leaning on his shoulder. Estella brings in the relatives, who continue their fawning and complaining. Miss Havisham, irritated, dismisses them, declaring they will "feast upon me" when she is laid out on the table. She then tells Pip it is her birthday and recounts the story of her jilted wedding day, when the clocks stopped at twenty minutes to nine. She implies her current state is a "curse upon him" (the absent bridegroom).

Pip and Estella play cards again. Estella treats Pip with disdain. She later takes him to be fed "dog-like." Wandering in the garden, Pip encounters a "pale young gentleman" (Herbert Pocket) who challenges him to a fight. Pip knocks him down repeatedly, winning the fight. Estella, observing, is delighted and allows Pip to kiss her cheek, though Pip feels it is a kiss given to a "common boy" and "worth nothing." Pip returns home, troubled by his "coarse" hands and "thick" boots, and his love for Estella.

**Chapter XII**
Pip is plagued by fear of legal consequences for the fight, but nothing comes of it. He continues his routine of pushing Miss Havisham in her chair every other day for several months. Miss Havisham often asks about Estella's beauty, appearing to "enjoy it greedily" when Pip confirms she is growing prettier. She whispers to Estella, "Break their hearts my pride and hope, break their hearts and have no mercy!" Pip begins to hum "Old Clem," a blacksmith's song, which Miss Havisham and Estella sometimes join. Pip remains ashamed of his home and trade.

Miss Havisham notices Pip is growing taller and decides it is time for him to be apprenticed. She asks Joe to come with Pip and his indentures. Mrs. Joe reacts with a violent "Ram-page," throwing a candlestick at Joe and cleaning the house furiously.

**Chapter XIII**
Joe, dressed uncomfortably in his Sunday best, accompanies Pip to Miss Havisham's. Mrs. Joe insists on coming along to Pumblechook's. Estella opens the gate and ignores them. In Miss Havisham's room, Joe, flustered, addresses Pip instead of Miss Havisham. Miss Havisham confirms Joe is Pip's guardian and asks about his apprenticeship. Joe confirms Pip's desire for the trade. Miss Havisham demands Pip's indentures and, upon seeing them, offers "five-and-twenty guineas" as a premium for Pip. Joe, astonished, accepts the money for Mrs. Joe's "satisfaction," expressing convoluted gratitude. Miss Havisham tells Pip he is not to return, as Joe is now his master.

At Pumblechook's, Mrs. Joe is delighted by the money. Pumblechook exaggerates his role in Pip's fortune, and they all go to the Town Hall, where Pip is formally bound as Joe's apprentice. Pumblechook treats Pip like a criminal, and people in the court seem to share this view. Afterward, they have a melancholy dinner at the Blue Boar, where Pumblechook continues to lecture Pip, and Mr. Wopsle performs a dramatic reading. Pip feels wretched, realizing he now hates Joe's trade.

**Chapter XIV**
Pip feels deep shame for his home and his life as a blacksmith, wanting to keep it hidden from Miss Havisham and Estella.
