Villefort, meanwhile, is plagued by a series of poisonings in his house: his in-laws, the Marquis and Madame de Saint-Méran, and his old servant Barrois, all die. Doctor d'Avrigny suspects poisoning and eventually accuses Madame de Villefort, revealing her motive (Valentine's inheritance for Edward). Noirtier (Villefort's paralyzed father) uses his eye movements to communicate, confirming the poisonings and indicating Madame de Villefort as the culprit. He also reveals he has been gradually immunizing Valentine with small doses of brucine.

Danglars, due to a false telegraph message orchestrated by Monte Cristo, loses a million francs in stock speculation. He later finds himself a victim of Luigi Vampa's brigands in Rome, who slowly extort his entire remaining fortune, leaving him with only 50,000 francs.

**Part 5: Resolution**

Albert, learning of his father Fernand's betrayal of Ali Pasha (revealed by Beauchamp's newspaper article, orchestrated by Monte Cristo and Haydée), confronts Monte Cristo at the Opera. Albert, in a fit of rage, challenges Monte Cristo to a duel. Monte Cristo accepts the challenge, seemingly willing to die.

Mercédès, having recognized Edmond as Monte Cristo, visits him privately. She begs him to spare her son, Albert. Monte Cristo, softened by her plea and revealing the truth of Fernand's betrayal and his own suffering, promises Albert will live. He declares he will sacrifice his own life instead. Mercédès, deeply moved, thanks him.

Monte Cristo prepares for the duel, but Albert, after speaking with his mother, publicly apologizes to Monte Cristo at the dueling ground, declaring Monte Cristo was justified in his revenge on Fernand. Monte Cristo is profoundly moved, recognizing Mercédès' noble sacrifice.

Albert, having renounced his father's name and fortune, decides to make a new life. Monte Cristo sends Mercédès the 3,000 francs he had buried, telling her it was his father's legacy, to live modestly. Mercédès accepts, resolving to live in a convent. Albert enlists in the Spahis in Africa to earn an honorable name.

At Benedetto's trial, Benedetto publicly denounces Villefort as his father, revealing his birth in Auteuil and how Villefort buried him alive. Villefort, overwhelmed by this revelation and the previous deaths in his family (and his wife's self-poisoning), goes completely mad, digging furiously in his garden for the buried child.

Madame de Villefort, confronted by her husband, poisons herself and Edward, leaving a note stating a "good mother cannot depart without her son." Villefort finds them dead and descends into madness.

Monte Cristo takes Maximilian Morrel, who is despairing over Valentine's death, to Monte Cristo Island. He reveals Valentine is alive, having survived the poisoning due to Noirtier's gradual immunization and Monte Cristo's intervention, allowing her to feign death. He reunites Maximilian and Valentine.

Monte Cristo then reveals his true identity as Edmond Dantès to Maximilian and Valentine in a letter. He bequeaths his immense fortune (including the Spada treasure and his properties) to Maximilian, asking him to marry Haydée (Ali Pasha's daughter), whom he loves as a daughter. He asks Valentine to give her inheritance (from her now mad father and deceased step-mother and brother) to the poor.

Monte Cristo reflects on his vengeance, finding it hollow despite its accomplishment. He has brought ruin and death, but no true happiness. He leaves with Haydée on his yacht, seeking peace and new life. He writes to Maximilian and Valentine: "There is neither happiness nor misery in the world; there is only the comparison of one state with another, nothing more. He who has felt the deepest grief is best able to experience supreme happiness. We must have felt what it is to die, Morrel, that we may appreciate the enjoyments of living. Live, then, and be happy... and never forget that until the day when God shall deign to reveal the future to man, all human wisdom is summed up in these two words,—‘_Wait and hope_.’"

Maximilian and Valentine are reunited and begin a new life together, filled with gratitude and love, while Monte Cristo and Haydée sail away, their ultimate destination unknown.

The Decameron begins with a Proem where the author, having suffered greatly from a "very high and noble passion" in his youth, wishes to provide comfort to afflicted ladies, particularly those suffering from love, as men have more distractions from melancholic thoughts. He purposes to recount one hundred stories over ten days, told by an "honourable company of seven ladies and three young men" formed during the recent deadly pestilence, interspersed with songs.

**Day the First**
The author describes the devastating Black Death that struck Florence in 1348, causing widespread death, moral decay, and the breakdown of laws and social norms. People adopted various strategies: some lived in isolated moderation, others indulged in wild revelry, some used aromatics to ward off contagion, and many fled the city. The dead were buried without traditional rites, often in mass graves. The plague also ravaged the countryside, leading to widespread abandonment of farms and livestock.
In this dire situation, seven young, noble, discreet, and beautiful ladies (Pampinea, Fiammetta, Filomena, Emilia, Lauretta, Neifile, and Elisa), aged between eighteen and twenty-eight, meet in the deserted church of Santa Maria Novella. Pampinea suggests they leave the afflicted city for the countryside to preserve their lives and spirits. Filomena wisely insists on male guidance for their company. Conveniently, three young, agreeable, and well-bred men (Pamfilo, Filostrato, and Dioneo), who are secretly enamored of some of the ladies, enter the church. Pampinea invites them to join, and after some initial hesitation from Neifile about potential scandal, they agree to form a company.
The next morning, they depart Florence for a beautiful palace on a hill two miles away. Pampinea is elected queen for the first day and establishes a strict, joyful order: assigning servants duties and prohibiting talk of the plague or outside sorrows. After dining, dancing, and resting, they gather, and Pampinea proposes storytelling as their main diversion. The theme for the first day is "that which is most agreeable unto each."

**The First Story (Pamfilo): Master Ciappelletto**
Ciappelletto, a notoriously wicked notary, is hired by the merchant Musciatto Franzesi for a debt collection in Burgundy. Ciappelletto falls ill and is lodged by two Florentine brothers. Fearing that his unconfessed sins will lead to his body being cast out (bringing shame and danger to them), Ciappelletto volunteers to make a "good" confession. He fabricates a detailed, utterly false confession of extreme piety and minor, righteous "sins" to a holy friar. The friar, completely deceived, believes him a saint. Ciappelletto dies, and the friar, recounting his "holy" confession, convinces the townsfolk he is a saint. He is buried with honors, becomes "Saint Ciappelletto," and is believed to perform miracles, illustrating God's mercy to pure-hearted supplicants despite the intercessor's true nature.

**The Second Story (Neifile): Abraham the Jew**
Jehannot de Chevigné, a Christian merchant in Paris, tries to convert his Jewish friend, Abraham. Abraham agrees to consider conversion but insists on first visiting Rome to observe the Pope and his clergy. Jehannot is distraught, fearing Abraham will be repulsed by the corruption he finds. Abraham travels to Rome, observes the widespread lust, gluttony, avarice, and simony among the clergy, from highest to lowest. He returns to Paris and tells Jehannot that, despite the clergy's depravity, Christianity must be truly divine to thrive amidst such corruption. He converts, is baptized Giovanni, and becomes a devout Christian.

**The Third Story (Filomena): Melchizedek the Jew**
Saladin, needing money, attempts to trick a wealthy Jew, Melchizedek, by asking which of the three religions (Jewish, Saracen, Christian) is the true one, hoping to seize his wealth for a perceived insult. Melchizedek, recognizing the trap, tells the parable of the three rings: a rich man with three equally beloved sons makes two identical copies of a precious ring (his legacy), giving one to each son. Thus, the true heir cannot be determined, and the question of which ring is the true one remains pending. Melchizedek applies this to the three religions. Saladin, impressed by his wisdom, reveals his true need. Melchizedek lends him the money, and they become friends.

**The Fourth Story (Dioneo): A Monk's Reproach**
A young, lusty monk in a solitary monastery seduces a country lass and brings her to his cell. The abbot, arising from sleep, overhears them and secretly observes the monk with the woman. The monk, realizing he's been seen, locks the girl in his cell and gives the abbot his key, pretending to go gather faggots. The abbot, intending to expose the monk, takes the key and goes to the cell. Seeing the beautiful girl, the abbot is tempted, succumbs to his own desires, and sleeps with her. The monk, hidden, witnesses this. When the abbot returns, he scolds the monk and orders his imprisonment. The monk replies, "Sir, I have not yet pertained long enough to the order of St. Benedict to have been able to learn every particular thereof, and you had not yet shown me that monks should make of women a means of mortification... but, now that you have shown it me... I will still to do as I have seen you do." The abbot, realizing his hypocrisy is exposed, pardons the monk, and they discreetly release the girl.

**The Fifth Story (Fiammetta): The Marchioness of Monferrato**
King Philippe le Borgne of France, hearing of the beauty of the Marchioness of Monferrato, falls in love with her. On his way to a Crusade, he plans an honorable detour to her castle, hoping to seduce her in her husband's absence. The Marchioness, discerning his intent, prepares a feast where every dish is made of hens. During dinner, the King jokes if only hens are born in her parts. She wittily replies that women, regardless of status, are all "of the same fashion here as elsewhere," meaning they are all women capable of fidelity and resistance. The King understands her rebuke, abandons his dishonorable intentions, and departs the next morning, ashamed.

**The Sixth Story (Emilia): An Honest Man's Reproof**
A Minor Friar inquisitor in Florence, more interested in money than faith, prosecutes a simple rich man for saying he had wine "Christ himself might drink." The inquisitor, threatening fire, forces the man to pay a large bribe. As penance, the man is made to wear a yellow cross and attend mass daily. After hearing a Gospel verse promising a hundredfold return for sacrifices, the man expresses pity for the friars, stating they will drown in the excessive broth they receive in the afterlife, referencing the daily offerings of excess broth given to the poor from the friars' table. The inquisitor, enraged by this public exposure of their gluttony and hypocrisy, dismisses him.

**The Seventh Story (Filostrato): Bergamino's Story**
Messer Cane della Scala, a magnificent nobleman of Verona, suddenly becomes miserly. Bergamino, a talented minstrel, is left unrewarded after a canceled festival. Finding himself destitute, Bergamino, by showing a mournful countenance, prompts Messer Cane to ask for a story. Bergamino tells of Primasso, a poor but learned scholar, who visits the famously generous Abbot of Cluny. The Abbot, seeing Primasso's shabby appearance, feels an uncharacteristic surge of avarice and delays dinner. Primasso, having brought three cakes, eats them one by one. The Abbot, increasingly ashamed of his meanness, eventually recognizes Primasso and his own lapse in generosity. He then honors Primasso with rich gifts. Messer Cane, understanding the allegory, laughs, acknowledges his own miserliness, and generously rewards Bergamino.

**The Eighth Story (Lauretta): Guglielmo Borsiere**
Messer Ermino de' Grimaldi, an immensely wealthy Genoese merchant, is renowned for his extreme avarice and squalor. Guglielmo Borsiere, a well-bred minstrel, visits Genoa and, hearing of Ermino's miserliness, desires to see him. Ermino, possessing some social grace, receives Guglielmo amicably and shows him his new, fine house. He asks Guglielmo to suggest a unique painting for his saloon. Guglielmo, after joking about "sneezings," suggests he paint "Liberality." Ermino is so shamed by this pointed remark that he completely changes his ways, becoming the most liberal and courteous gentleman in Genoa.

**The Ninth Story (Elisa): The King of Cyprus**
In the days after the Holy Land's conquest, a noblewoman from Gascony is robbed and abused in Cyprus. She seeks redress from the King, but is told he is so weak and pusillanimous that he endures countless insults himself without seeking justice. The lady, despairing, decides to shame the King into action. She tearfully approaches him, not to demand justice for herself, but to ask him to teach her how he endures his own insults so meekly, hoping to learn patience. The King, shamed by her words, awakens from his lethargy, severely avenges her wrong, and subsequently becomes a just and strong ruler.

**The Tenth Story (Pampinea): Master Alberto of Bologna**
Master Alberto, a very old but famous Bolognese physician, falls ardently in love with the beautiful widow Madam Malgherida de' Ghisolieri. He frequently passes by her house. She and her friends mock his elderly passion. One day, they invite him in and politely ask why an old, wise man would fall in love, especially when she is courted by young men. Master Alberto wittily replies that just as some women (like them) prefer the unpleasant leaves of a leek to its desirable head, so too might they prefer young, foolish lovers to an old, wise one. The ladies are abashed by his shrewd retort and accept his love, promising to be at his service.

**Day the First Conclusion:**
The company applauds Pampinea's story. Pampinea, having completed her day as queen, passes the laurel wreath to Filomena. Filomena establishes the schedule for the next two days: Friday will be devoted to prayers and the Passion of Christ, and Saturday to personal hygiene and rest, in reverence to the Virgin Mary. They will then move to a new location. The theme for the next storytelling day (Sunday) will be "those who, after being baffled by divers chances, have won at last to a joyful issue beyond their hope." Dioneo is granted the privilege to tell any story he wishes, last, on any day. Emilia sings a joyful song about self-love.

**Day the Second**
The company enjoys a morning walk, dines, dances, and then reassembles in the cool shade. Filomena, as queen, commands Neifile to begin the day's stories.

**The First Story (Neifile): Martellino**
Martellino, a Florentine entertainer, arrives in Treviso with two companions, Stecchi and Marchese. The city is in an uproar over the supposed miracles of St. Arrigo. Martellino decides to feign lameness to get close to the saint's body. He contorts his body, appears paralyzed, and is carried to the cathedral. He dramatically "recovers" upon touching the body, eliciting shouts of praise. A Florentine recognizes him and exposes him as a fraud. The crowd violently beats Martellino. To save him, Marchese falsely accuses Martellino of being a cutpurse, leading to his arrest by city officers. He is nearly hanged for theft but is eventually rescued by influential friends, who convince the Prince of his innocence. He returns home safe.

**The Second Story (Filostrato): Rinaldo d'Asti**
Rinaldo d'Asti, a merchant, travels from Bologna. He joins three men, unaware they are highwaymen. He boasts of his morning prayer to St. Julian, which always ensures him good lodging. The highwaymen rob him near Castel Guglielmo, leaving him stripped and barefoot in the snow, mocking his saint. Rinaldo struggles to reach the town, but the gates are shut. He shelters under a projecting house. The house belongs to a beautiful widow, the Marquis Azzo's mistress. The Marquis unexpectedly cancels his visit, leaving a bath and supper prepared. The widow's maid hears Rinaldo's lamenting. The widow, taking pity, lets him in, bathes him, clothes him in her late husband's attire, and then, feeling aroused, seduces him. The next morning, Rinaldo receives money and clothes. The highwaymen are caught for another crime, and Rinaldo's belongings are restored. He returns home safe and rich, thanking God and St. Julian.

**The Third Story (Pampinea): Three Young Men**
Messer Tedaldo, a wealthy Florentine gentleman, dies, leaving three sons (Lamberto, Tedaldo, Agolante) a vast fortune. They squander it on extravagant living. They then move to London, become usurers, and rebuild their wealth, eventually returning to Florence. They send their nephew, Alessandro, to manage their affairs in England. War breaks out, and Alessandro loses everything. Meanwhile, the three brothers in Florence resume their lavish spending and are imprisoned for debt. Alessandro, disheartened, decides to return. He encounters a company led by a young abbot, who is secretly the King of England's daughter, fleeing an arranged marriage. She falls for Alessandro, they secretly marry, and she uses her royal status to free his uncles, restore their fortunes, and elevate Alessandro to an earldom, reconciling the King with his daughter.

**The Fourth Story (Lauretta): Landolfo Ruffolo**
Landolfo Ruffolo, a rich merchant of Ravello, loses his fortune trading in Cyprus. He turns corsair, plundering Turkish ships, and recovers double his wealth. Resolved to return home, he sails in a small vessel. Near Corfu, he is captured by two Genoese carracks, who steal his goods and scuttle his ship. A storm then wrecks the carrack he is on. Landolfo survives, clinging to a floating chest for a day and a night. He is rescued by a poor woman on the coast of Corfu. The chest, which he thought worthless, is full of precious jewels. He rewards the woman, sells the jewels, and returns to Ravello, richer than ever, never to trade again.

**The Fifth Story (Fiammetta): Andreuccio of Perugia**
Andreuccio, a naive horse-courser from Perugia, comes to Naples to buy horses. He carelessly displays his money. A beautiful Sicilian courtesan notices him. An old woman, who knew Andreuccio's father, greets him, which the courtesan observes. The courtesan, claiming to be his long-lost sister, lures him to her house in a disreputable street. She tells him a fabricated story of their shared family history. Believing her, he stays for supper. In the night, needing to relieve himself, he falls through a rotten plank in an outhouse into a cesspit. The courtesan steals his money. He climbs out, finds himself locked out, and is threatened by her bully. Despairing, he encounters two thieves planning to rob the tomb of a recently buried archbishop, who wears a valuable ruby ring. He agrees to help. They lower him into the tomb. He takes the ruby for himself, then passes out other items. The thieves abandon him in the tomb, but he is saved when new robbers open the tomb, whom he frightens away. He escapes with the ruby and returns to his inn, where he finds his companions. He leaves Naples immediately, with the ruby as his profit.

**The Sixth Story (Emilia): Madam Beritola**
Madam Beritola, wife of Arrighetto Capece, flees Naples pregnant with her son Giusfredi after King Manfred's defeat. She gives birth to Scacciato on Lipari. Pirates then kidnap both children and her nurse. Beritola is left alone on the deserted island of Ponza and lives like a wild creature, sustained by a she-goat and its kids. Months later, Currado Malespina finds her and, recognizing her noble origins, brings her and the goats to his castle in Lunigiana. The captured children are sold as slaves to Messer Guasparrino d'Oria in Genoa. The nurse renames Giusfredi to Giannotto to protect him. Years pass. Giannotto (now 16) leaves service and, hearing his father is imprisoned, wanders until he serves Currado Malespina. He and Currado's daughter, Spina, fall in love and are caught by Currado, who imprisons them. When Sicily revolts, Giannotto reveals his true identity. Currado, confirming his story with Beritola, marries him to Spina, thus restoring his honor and hers. Scacciato is found, married, and the entire family (including the freed Arrighetto) is reunited and restored to high estate.

**The Seventh Story (Pamfilo): The Soldan's Daughter Alatiel**
Alatiel, the beautiful daughter of the Soldan of Babylon, is sent to marry the King of Algarve. A storm wrecks her ship on Majorca, and she is the sole survivor. Pericone, a gentleman, rescues her and becomes infatuated. He seduces her by getting her drunk. Pericone's brother, Marato, also desires her. He murders Pericone and abducts Alatiel, taking her on a ship. The two Genoese shipmasters also fall for her, murder Marato, and fight over her, resulting in one's death and the other's injury. Alatiel then becomes the mistress of the Prince of Morea, who treats her as his wife. The Duke of Athens, the Prince's kinsman, falls for her, murders the Prince, and abducts Alatiel. Constantine, son of the Emperor of Constantinople and kinsman to the Duke's wife, also falls for Alatiel. He tricks the Duchess into letting him abduct Alatiel. He takes her to Chios. Osbech, King of the Turks, captures Chios and takes Alatiel as his wife. Osbech is then killed in battle. His servant, Antiochus, desires Alatiel, and they become lovers, fleeing to Rhodes with Osbech's treasures. Antiochus falls ill and dies, entrusting Alatiel and the treasures to a Cypriot merchant. The merchant, passing her off as his wife, also becomes her lover. Eventually, in Cyprus, Alatiel is recognized by Antigonus, a former servant of her father. She invents a story of being housed in a convent after shipwreck, thereby preserving her honor despite her many lovers. Antigonus returns her to the Soldan, who, believing her virtuous and untouched, sends her to marry the King of Algarve.

**The Eighth Story (Elisa): The Count of Antwerp**
Gautier, Count of Antwerp, is appointed regent of France by King Charles. The King's son's wife falls for him and tries to seduce him. He rejects her, citing loyalty to the King. Enraged, she falsely accuses him of attempted rape. Gautier, to avoid public scandal, flees to England with his two young children, Louis and Violante, changing their names to Perrot and Jeannette. He places them with noble families, who raise them. Gautier becomes a humble horseboy in Ireland. Years later, the Queen confesses her lie on her deathbed. The King, regretting his actions, seeks Gautier and his children. Gautier, now aged and changed, returns to England, finds his son, Perrot, is a renowned marshal and his daughter, Jeannette, is married to a marshal's son. He reveals his identity to them and then to the King. The King reinstates Gautier, honors his children, and gives them wealth.

**The Ninth Story (Filomena): Bernabo of Genoa**
Bernabo Lomellini, a Genoese merchant, boasts to other merchants in Paris of his wife Ginevra's unparalleled chastity. Ambrogiuolo of Piacenza bets him that he can corrupt her. Ambrogiuolo travels to Genoa, bribes Ginevra's maid, and has himself hidden in a chest in Ginevra's bedchamber. While she sleeps, he observes a mole under her breast and steals a purse and girdle. He returns to Paris and "proves" his conquest to Bernabo with these details. Bernabo, enraged, orders a servant to murder Ginevra. The servant, taking pity, spares her, giving her his clothes and letting her flee. Disguised as a man named Sicurano, Ginevra serves the Soldan of Babylon, earning his trust. At a fair in Acre, she recognizes her stolen items in Ambrogiuolo's possession. She confronts him, brings him before the Soldan, and exposes his deception. Ambrogiuolo is executed, smeared with honey, and left to be eaten by insects. Ginevra reveals her identity, is reunited with a repentant Bernabo, and returns to Genoa rich and honored.

**The Tenth Story (Dioneo): Paganino of Monaco**
Messer Ricciardo di Chinzica, an old, learned, but sexually inept judge in Pisa, marries the young and beautiful Bartolomea. He imposes a strict "calendar" of fast days and saints' days, severely limiting their marital relations. Bartolomea is unhappy. Paganino da Mare, a famous corsair, abducts her during a fishing excursion. Paganino is a passionate lover, and Bartolomea quickly embraces a joyful life with him, forgetting her husband's rules. Ricciardo discovers her whereabouts and, desperate to retrieve her, travels to Monaco. Paganino agrees to let her choose. She confronts Ricciardo, mocks his former neglect, and explicitly states her preference for Paganino's vigorous love-making over her husband's asceticism. She refuses to return. Ricciardo, heartbroken, returns to Pisa, where he dies of chagrin, repeating "The ill hole will have no holidays." Paganino marries Bartolomea, and they live happily.

**Day the Second Conclusion:**
The company laughs at Dioneo's story. Filomena passes the crown to Filostrato. Filostrato, revealing his own history of unhappy love, sets the theme for Day 4: "of those whose loves have had unhappy endings." Lauretta sings a melancholy song about unrequited love and longing for death, which some of the company interpret playfully.

**Day the Third**
The company moves to a third, even more beautiful palace and garden. They continue their routine of enjoying nature, dining, and relaxing. Neifile, as queen, commands Filostrato to begin the stories.

**The First Story (Filostrato): Masetto of Lamporecchio**
Masetto, a lusty young countryman, learns of a convent where all the nuns and the abbess are young. The previous gardener, Nuto, complained about the low pay and the nuns' demanding nature. Masetto, desiring the nuns, feigns to be deaf and dumb and gets hired as the new gardener. The nuns, believing him to be simple and harmless, begin to use him for their sexual pleasure, one by one. Eventually, the abbess herself, observing him, also takes him as a lover. Masetto, overwhelmed by their demands, breaks his silence and explains he cannot satisfy all nine women. The abbess and nuns, realizing their secret is out and to prevent scandal, agree to keep him as their bailiff, fabricating a miracle for his recovered speech. Masetto lives a life of pleasure and returns home rich in old age.

**The Second Story (Pampinea): A Horsekeeper and King Agilulf's Wife**
A horsekeeper in King Agilulf of Lombardy's service falls in love with Queen Theodolinda. He observes the King's discreet nightly visits to the Queen's chamber. The horsekeeper, mimicking the King's attire and actions, secretly visits the Queen, who mistakes him for her husband, and they lie together. The King, realizing his wife has been deceived, wisely chooses not to expose the scandal. Instead, he discretely identifies the culprit by feeling the pulses of his sleeping household and cutting a lock of the horsekeeper's hair. The horsekeeper, realizing he's been marked, cuts the hair of all his fellow servants. The King, seeing this, understands the man's wit and issues a veiled warning to the entire household to "do it no more," thus avoiding public shame while acknowledging the deception.

**The Third Story (Filomena): A Lady and a Friar**
A noble Florentine lady, unhappily married to a wool-monger, loves a gentleman. She uses a pious but naive friar as an unwitting intermediary. She "confesses" to the friar that the gentleman is bothering her. The friar, believing her, rebukes the gentleman. The lady then "confesses" that the gentleman sent her gifts, which she gives to the friar to return. She later "confesses" that the gentleman tried to enter her house by climbing a tree. The friar, increasingly indignant, keeps passing on these messages, unknowingly facilitating the lovers' communication and allowing them to arrange a secret tryst. The lady and her lover mock the friar's simplicity.

**The Fourth Story (Pamfilo): Dom Felice and Fra Puccio**
Fra Puccio, a rich but simple-minded man from Florence, becomes extremely devout, neglecting his young and beautiful wife, Isabetta. Dom Felice, a clever and lusty monk, befriends Fra Puccio and desires Isabetta. Dom Felice convinces Fra Puccio to undertake a grueling forty-day penance: standing cruciform all night, every night, in a room where he can see the sky, to achieve sainthood and be cured of jealousy. While Fra Puccio performs his penance, Dom Felice secretly visits Isabetta, who eagerly becomes his lover. One night, Fra Puccio hears them and calls out. Isabetta, quick-witted, claims she is "tossing" in bed due to her fasting. Fra Puccio, believing her, is fooled. The affair continues discreetly, providing mutual pleasure to Dom Felice and Isabetta.

**The Fifth Story (Elisa): Ricciardo, surnamed Il Zima**
Messer Francesco Vergellesi, a wealthy but avaricious gentleman of Pistoia, desires Ricciardo "Il Zima"'s beautiful palfrey. Ricciardo, who loves Francesco's virtuous wife, Caterina, offers the horse in exchange for a private conversation with her in Francesco's presence. Francesco agrees, instructing Caterina to remain silent. Ricciardo passionately declares his love to Caterina. When she remains silent due to her husband's command, Ricciardo cleverly answers *as if he were her*, promising a tryst when Francesco leaves for Milan. Caterina, moved by his words and his gift (the palfrey), later fulfills the promise when her husband is away, and they become lovers.

**The Sixth Story (Fiammetta): Ricciardo Minutolo and Catella**
Ricciardo Minutolo, a nobleman of Naples, falls in love with Catella, the beautiful and fiercely jealous wife of Filippello Fighinolfi. Ricciardo, unable to win her openly, feigns disinterest and then, subtly, implies that Filippello is having an affair and plans to meet a woman at a public bath. He advises Catella to go there in disguise to confront her husband. Catella, consumed by jealousy, goes to the bath. In the dark, she believes she is with Filippello and furiously rails at him for his supposed infidelity and her own sexual neglect. Ricciardo then reveals his true identity. Catella, initially enraged, eventually makes peace and becomes his discreet lover, finding greater satisfaction with him than her husband.

**The Seventh Story (Emilia): Tedaldo Elisei**
Tedaldo Elisei, a Florentine nobleman, is deeply in love with Madam Ermellina, who suddenly spurns him. Heartbroken, he leaves Florence, becoming a wealthy merchant in Cyprus. After seven years, hearing a song he wrote about his love, he returns disguised as a pilgrim. He discovers his brothers have mistakenly identified a murdered stranger as him and accused Ermellina's husband, Aldobrandino, of the murder. Tedaldo learns the true murderers were innkeepers who killed the stranger. He reveals himself to Ermellina, who is overjoyed. He then exposes the true culprits to the authorities, securing Aldobrandino's release. He reconciles his brothers with Aldobrandino and resumes his discreet affair with Ermellina.

**The Eighth Story (Lauretta): Ferondo in Purgatory**
Ferondo, a dull-witted and jealous farmer, is married to a beautiful woman. The abbot of a nearby convent desires her. He convinces the wife that he can cure Ferondo's jealousy by sending him to "purgatory." The abbot gives Ferondo a powerful sleeping powder. Ferondo falls into a deep coma and is buried alive. The abbot then secretly moves Ferondo to a hidden prison cell in the convent, where an accomplice monk beats him daily and tells him he is in purgatory, suffering for his jealousy. The abbot, meanwhile, enjoys the wife's favors, and she becomes pregnant. To explain the pregnancy, Ferondo is "resurrected" and told the child is a miracle, cured of his jealousy. He is reunited with his wife, and the abbot continues his affair discreetly.

**The Ninth Story (Gillette de Narbonne):**
Gillette, a physician's daughter, secretly loves Bertrand de Roussillon, a count. The King of France suffers from an incurable fistula. Gillette, using her father's medical knowledge, cures the King. As a reward, she demands Bertrand as her husband. Bertrand, despising her lower birth, marries her unwillingly and flees to Florence, joining a war. He sends word to Gillette that he will only accept her as his wife if she can bear him a child and produce his ring, which he never removes. Gillette, in disguise, travels to Florence, discovers Bertrand's current infatuation with another woman, and, with the help of that woman's mother, orchestrates a bed trick. She takes the other woman's place in Bertrand's bed, conceives two sons, and obtains his ring. She then presents herself to Bertrand, fulfilling his conditions. Bertrand, impressed by her resourcefulness, constancy, and the children, finally accepts her as his true wife.

**The Tenth Story (Dioneo): Alibech and Rustico**
Alibech, a very naive young woman from Capsa, seeking to serve God, journeys to the desert of Thebais. She meets Rustico, a hermit, who is tempted by her beauty. He devises a "service to God": to "put the devil in hell." He explains his erect penis is the "devil" and her vagina is "hell," and the act is to punish the devil. Alibech, in her innocence, eagerly participates, finding the act delightful and frequently requesting to "put the devil in hell." Rustico, overworked, eventually claims the "devil" is chastened. Alibech complains her "hell" is not. Meanwhile, Alibech's family dies in a fire, leaving her rich. Neerbale finds her and takes her back to Capsa, marrying her. Alibech, still naive, tells other women that serving God means "putting the devil in hell," leading to much laughter and the proverb spreading.

**Day the Third Conclusion:**
The company applauds Dioneo's story. Emilia, as queen, passes the crown to Filostrato. Filostrato, who has suffered in love, sets the theme for Day 4: "those whose loves have had unhappy ending." Lauretta sings a melancholy song about unrequited love.

**Day the Fourth**
The author provides a personal prologue, defending himself against critics who accuse him of pleasing women too much, being too old for such themes, or writing in the vernacular. He illustrates the power of natural desire with a partial story of Filippo Balducci, who raises his son in isolation, but the son, upon seeing women for the first time, immediately desires "green geese" (women). The author argues that his stories, like all things, can be used for good or ill, depending on the reader's disposition, and that he writes for the solace of idle women.
The company enjoys the garden in the morning, dines, then reassembles. Filostrato, as king, commands Fiammetta to begin the day's stories.

**The First Story (Fiammetta): Ghismonda and Guiscardo**
Tancred, Prince of Salerno, dotes on his only daughter, Ghismonda. Widowed, she secretly takes a low-born but noble-hearted servant, Guiscardo, as her lover. Tancred discovers them by hiding in her room. He has Guiscardo secretly strangled and sends Ghismonda his heart in a golden cup. Ghismonda, with profound dignity, places the heart in the cup, pours a prepared poison over it, delivers a defiant speech praising Guiscardo's love and worth, and drinks the poisoned water. She dies holding the heart. Tancred, too late regretting his cruelty, buries their bodies together in a single tomb.

**The Second Story (Pampinea): Fra Alberto**
Berto della Massa, a wicked man, becomes Fra Alberto, a supposedly holy friar in Venice. He becomes a trusted confessor to many, including the vain and foolish Madam Lisetta. Fra Alberto, attracted to Lisetta, convinces her that the Archangel Gabriel is in love with her and will visit her, taking on Fra Alberto's body. He repeatedly sleeps with her. Lisetta, in her vanity, boasts about her angelic lover to a gossip. The news spreads. Lisetta's brothers-in-law, hearing the rumors, set a trap. Fra Alberto, warned, escapes by jumping naked into the Grand Canal. He is rescued by a poor man, who then, for a fee, disguises him as a wild man in a "bear-suit" for a local festival. He is paraded through St. Mark's Square, recognized, shamed, and imprisoned by his order.

**The Third Story (Lauretta): Three Young Men and Three Sisters**
Three sisters (Ninetta, Maddalena, Bertella) flee Marseilles to Crete with their lovers (Restagnone, Folco, Ughetto). Restagnone, Ninetta's lover, grows tired of her and falls for a Cretan lady. Ninetta, consumed by jealousy, poisons Restagnone. The Duke of Crete arrests Ninetta. Maddalena, to save her sister from execution, agrees to sleep with the Duke. Folco, Maddalena's lover, discovers her betrayal and kills her in a jealous rage. He then flees with Ninetta. Ughetto and Bertella are falsely accused of Maddalena's murder, but bribe their way to freedom and flee to Rhodes, where they die in poverty.

**The Fourth Story (Elisa): Gerbino and the King of Tunis's Daughter**
Gerbino, King Guglielmo of Sicily's grandson, falls in love with the beautiful daughter of the King of Tunis, having only heard of her. She reciprocates. The King of Tunis arranges her marriage to the King of Granada and receives King Guglielmo's pledge of safe passage for her. Gerbino, driven by love, intercepts her ship. The Saracens, to prevent her capture, murder her before Gerbino's eyes and throw her body into the sea. Gerbino boards the ship, slays many, retrieves her body, and buries it. King Guglielmo, honoring his pledge, executes his grandson Gerbino. Both lovers die violently without ever truly meeting.

**The Fifth Story (Filomena): Lisabetta and the Pot of Basil**
Lisabetta, a young woman in Messina, falls in love with Lorenzo, a Pisan servant of her three merchant brothers. Their secret affair is discovered by the eldest brother. To prevent scandal, the brothers murder Lorenzo and bury him. Lisabetta, distraught by his unexplained absence, is visited by his ghost in a dream, who reveals his murder and burial place. She secretly exhumes his head, places it in a pot of basil, and mourns over it constantly, watering the plant with her tears. Her brothers, noticing her strange devotion, steal the pot and discover the head. Fearing exposure, they flee to Naples. Lisabetta dies of grief, still longing for her basil pot.

**The Sixth Story (Pamfilo): Andrevuola and Gabriotto**
Andrevuola, a young gentlewoman of Brescia, secretly marries her lover, Gabriotto. One night, she dreams of a dark figure carrying him away. The next night, Gabriotto tells her a dream of a black greyhound attacking his heart. He then suddenly dies in her arms. Andrevuola, desperate to protect her honor and secretly bury him, enlists her maid. They carry his body to his house, but are intercepted by the city watch. The Provost questions Andrevuola, who reveals the truth of his natural death. The Provost, lusting after her, attempts to force himself on her. Her father, Messer Negro, intervenes, and she is cleared. Out of disgust with the world, Andrevuola and her maid become nuns.

**The Seventh Story (Emilia): Simona and Pasquino**
Simona, a poor Florentine spinner, falls in love with Pasquino, a wool-monger's servant. They arrange a secret meeting in a garden. As they sit under a sage bush, Pasquino rubs a sage leaf on his teeth and suddenly dies, his body swelling and darkening. Simona is accused of poisoning him. To prove her innocence, she rubs a similar sage leaf on her teeth before the judge and dies in the same way. The judge orders the sage bush cut down, revealing a large venomous toad underneath, the true cause of death. Simona and Pasquino are buried together.

**The Eighth Story (Neifile): Girolamo and Salvestra**
Girolamo, son of a wealthy Florentine merchant, loves Salvestra, a tailor's daughter. His mother, disapproving, sends him to Paris. He returns two years later to find Salvestra married. He secretly enters her house at night and finds her and her husband asleep. He lies beside her, professing his undying love, and dies of a broken heart. Salvestra, discovering his death, consults her husband, who advises carrying the body to Girolamo's door. At Girolamo's funeral, Salvestra is overcome with grief, throws herself on his body, and also dies. They are buried together in the same tomb.

**The Ninth Story (Elisa): Sir Guillaume de Roussillon and Sir Guillaume de Guardestaing**
Sir Guillaume de Roussillon and Sir Guillaume de Guardestaing, two Provençal knights, are close friends. Roussillon's wife and Guardestaing fall in love and begin an affair. Roussillon discovers them. His love for Guardestaing turns to hatred. He feigns a tournament invitation, ambushes Guardestaing, kills him, and tears out his heart. He has the heart cooked and serves it to his wife. When she praises the dish, he reveals its true nature. Horrified, she curses him and throws herself from a high window to her death. Roussillon flees. The two lovers are buried in the same tomb.

**The Tenth Story (Dioneo): A Physician's Wife and Ruggieri**
Master Mazzeo, an old, famous surgeon in Salerno, is married to a beautiful young woman. He neglects her sexually. She takes a lover, Ruggieri, a noble but disreputable youth. The physician prepares a powerful sleeping draught for a patient. Ruggieri, thirsty, drinks it and appears dead. The wife and her maid, thinking him dead, hide him in a chest outside. Two usurers steal the chest. Ruggieri awakens inside the usurers' house, is discovered, and accused of theft. The wife's maid, to save Ruggieri and her mistress's honor, fabricates a story: she confesses to the physician that Ruggieri was her lover and she gave him the water. She then tells the magistrate a modified version, blaming the usurers for theft. Ruggieri is released, and the usurers are fined. The wife and Ruggieri continue their affair.

**Day the Fourth Conclusion:**
Dioneo's story lightens the mood. Filostrato passes the crown to Fiammetta. Fiammetta sets the theme for Day 5: "that which hath happily betided lovers after sundry cruel and unfortunate adventures." Filostrato sings a sad song lamenting his own unrequited love and betrayal.

**Day the Fifth**
The company enjoys the morning in the gardens, dines, and reassembles by the fountain. Fiammetta, as queen, commands Pamfilo to begin the stories.

**The First Story (Pamfilo): Cimon and Iphigenia**
Cimon, a brutish, dull-witted nobleman's son in Cyprus, is transformed by love after seeing the beautiful Iphigenia asleep. He learns philosophy, music, and knightly skills. Iphigenia is betrothed to Pasimondas of Rhodes. Cimon abducts her on her way to her wedding. A storm wrecks his ship on Rhodes, where he is imprisoned. Lysimachus, a Rhodian noble who loves Pasimondas's sister Cassandra, helps Cimon escape. They storm the wedding feast, abduct Iphigenia and Cassandra, and flee to Crete. They marry their beloveds and, after a period of exile, are reconciled with their families.

**The Second Story (Emilia): Costanza and Martuccio Gomito**
Costanza, a noble Lipari girl, loves Martuccio Gomito. Her father rejects him for his poverty. Martuccio becomes a corsair to gain wealth, but is captured and presumed dead. Costanza, despairing, sets herself adrift in a boat, hoping to die. She lands in Susa, Barbary, and is sheltered by a good woman. Meanwhile, Martuccio, using his wisdom, has become a favored advisor to the King of Tunis, who is at war. Costanza learns he is alive, finds him, and they are joyfully reunited. The King, impressed by their story, gifts them, and they return to Lipari, marry, and live happily.

**The Third Story (Elisa): Pietro Boccamazza and Agnolella**
Pietro Boccamazza, a Roman nobleman, loves Agnolella, a plebeian. His family forbids the marriage. They decide to elope to Anagni. On their journey, they are ambushed by footmen. Agnolella flees into a wood. Pietro is captured, but then escapes when his captors are attacked by a larger group of footmen. Lost and terrified, he spends the night in a tree. Agnolella, also lost, finds refuge with an old couple, then at a castle with a noble lady. Pietro, guided by shepherds, eventually reaches the same castle. They are joyfully reunited, marry with the lady's blessing, and return to Rome, reconciling with their families.

**The Fourth Story (Filostrato): Ricciardo and Caterina**
Ricciardo, a young gentleman, loves Caterina, the beautiful daughter of Messer Lizio da Valbona. Caterina, complaining of heat, asks to sleep in an outdoor gallery to hear the nightingale. Her parents reluctantly agree. Ricciardo scales a wall to join her. They spend the night in amorous delight. Messer Lizio discovers them asleep, unclothed, and embracing. Instead of raging, he wisely decides to marry them immediately to avoid scandal, noting Ricciardo's good qualities. Ricciardo agrees, and they are married, publicly celebrating their union.

**The Fifth Story (Neifile): Giannole and Minghino**
Guidotto da Cremona, dying in Fano, entrusts his young daughter to his friend Giacomino da Pavia. Giacomino moves to Faenza, raising the girl. She grows up beautiful, and two young men, Giannole and Minghino, fall in love with her. Both, unaware of the other's plan, bribe Giacomino's servants to arrange a secret tryst. A misunderstanding leads to both groups of armed men arriving simultaneously, causing a brawl. Many are arrested, including Giannole and Minghino. Giacomino reveals he found the girl, not knowing her parents. A witness identifies her as Agnesa, daughter of Bernabuccio, lost during a siege. Giannole, now her brother, is released, and Agnesa marries Minghino.

**The Sixth Story (Pampinea): Gianni di Procida and Restituta**
Gianni di Procida, from a small island near Ischia, loves Restituta, a noble Ischian girl, who reciprocates. He often swims to Ischia to see her. She is kidnapped by Sicilian corsairs and presented to King Frederick of Sicily, who houses her in his garden. Gianni tracks her down and enters her chamber at night. They fall asleep together. King Frederick discovers them and orders them burned alive in Palermo. Ruggieri dell'Oria, the King's admiral, recognizes Gianni (whose uncle helped Frederick become king). Ruggieri intercedes, reminding the King of his debt to Gianni's family. The King, shamed, pardons them, has them marry, and sends them home with gifts.

**The Seventh Story (Lauretta): Teodoro and Violante**
Messer Amerigo, a Trapanese gentleman, buys Teodoro (believing him a Turk), a boy of noble mien, from corsairs. He frees Teodoro, baptizes him Pietro, and makes him his steward. Pietro and Amerigo's daughter, Violante, fall in love. Caught in a hailstorm, they take shelter and consummate their love, later continuing their secret meetings. Violante becomes pregnant. Pietro is condemned to be hanged. On his way to execution, an Armenian ambassador, Fineo, recognizes Pietro (his long-lost son Teodoro) by a birthmark. Fineo intervenes, and Teodoro is pardoned. Messer Amerigo, initially furious, learns of his daughter's pregnancy and eventually agrees to the marriage. Teodoro and Violante marry and live happily.

**The Eighth Story (Filomena): Nastagio degli Onesti**
Nastagio degli Onesti, a rich Ravenna youth, loves a proud lady of the Traversari family, who scorns him. He spends his wealth trying to win her, to no avail. He moves to Chiassi, where, one Friday, he witnesses a horrifying spectral chase: a knight relentlessly hunts, kills, and dismembers a naked lady, feeding her heart to his dogs. The knight explains this is his eternal punishment for suicide due to her cruelty, and hers for her disdain. Nastagio, seeing this recurring weekly, arranges a dinner in the same spot for his family and the scornful lady. She witnesses the gruesome scene and, terrified of a similar fate, agrees to marry Nastagio. They marry and live happily. The spectacle also makes other Ravenna ladies more amenable to their lovers.

**The Ninth Story (Fiammetta): Federigo degli Alberighi**
Coppo di Borghese Domenichi recounts the story of Federigo degli Alberighi, a noble Florentine youth renowned for prowess and courtesy. He falls in love with Madam Giovanna, a virtuous married lady, and squanders all his wealth to impress her. Left with only a small farm and his prized falcon, he lives in poverty. Giovanna's husband dies, leaving her a rich widow with a son. The son befriends Federigo and desires his falcon. The boy falls ill, and believing the falcon will cure him, asks his mother for it. Giovanna, despite knowing Federigo's poverty and the falcon's importance to him, visits him to request it. Federigo, having nothing else to offer her for dinner, kills and serves her his beloved falcon. Upon learning this, Giovanna is deeply moved by his sacrifice. After her son dies, she marries Federigo, preferring "a man that lacketh of riches than riches that lack of a man." They live happily, and he manages his wealth wisely.

**The Tenth Story (Dioneo): Pietro di Vinciolo**
Pietro di Vinciolo, a wealthy Perugian, marries the lusty, hot-blooded Bartolomea, but is himself more inclined to other "ends." Bartolomea, realizing her husband's neglect, takes a lover. One evening, Pietro returns unexpectedly while her lover is in the house. She hides the lover under a hen-coop. Pietro recounts a story of a friend finding a man hidden in his wife's house and condemns the wife. Later, an ass in an adjoining stable accidentally steps on the lover's fingers, making him cry out. Pietro discovers him. The wife, quick-witted, feigns anger, blames Pietro for his drunkenness and neglect, and then subtly proposes a truce: she will be discreet in her affairs if he finds his own satisfaction elsewhere. Pietro, seeing an opportunity for his "lewd ends," agrees.

**Day the Fifth Conclusion:**
Dioneo's story, though somewhat indelicate, causes much laughter. Fiammetta passes the crown to Elisa, charging her to ensure the next day's actions match her beauty. Elisa, embarrassed but composed, sets a free theme for Day 8: "of the tricks that all day long women play men or men women or men one another." The ladies then explore the "Ladies' Valley" and bathe in a lake. Pamfilo sings a love song, alluding to his own love for Fiammetta.

**Day the Sixth**
The company enjoys the morning in the garden, dines, and reassembles for storytelling. A comical argument breaks out between two servants, Licisca and Tindaro, about women's chastity. Licisca loudly asserts that no woman is a virgin when she marries and that wives frequently deceive their husbands. Dioneo jokingly agrees. The queen, Emilia, commands Filomena to begin the day's stories.

**The First Story (Filomena): Madam Oretta**
A gentleman, riding with the noble Madam Oretta, offers to "carry" her on horseback with a story. He tells a good story very poorly, repeating himself and mixing up details. Madam Oretta, subtly but firmly, interrupts him, saying, "Sir, this horse of yours hath too hard a trot; wherefore I pray you be pleased to set me down." The gentleman, understanding her witty critique, stops the story and changes the subject.

**The Second Story (Pampinea): Cisti the Baker**
Cisti, a wealthy baker, uses his wit to serve Messer Geri Spina and papal ambassadors his excellent white wine without being presumptuous. He conspicuously drinks the wine in front of his shop, prompting Messer Geri to inquire. Cisti serves them. Later, when Messer Geri sends a servant with an inappropriately large flask, Cisti refuses, saying Geri sent him "to the Arno" (to dilute the fine wine). Messer Geri, understanding the subtle rebuke, sends a proper flask. Cisti then sends a whole cask of wine to Geri's house, acknowledging Geri's understanding.

**The Third Story (Lauretta): Madam Nonna de' Pulci**
Messer Dego della Ratta, marshal for King Robert, paid a husband 500 florins to lie with his wife (the Bishop of Florence's kinswoman). The scandal became public. The Bishop, Messer Antonio d'Orso, feigned ignorance. One day, at a public event, the Bishop points out the beautiful Madam Nonna de' Pulci to the marshal and jokingly asks her if she could conquer him. Madam Nonna, realizing the Bishop's jab about her kinswoman, retorts that she would "want good money," effectively shaming both the marshal for his past act and the Bishop for his ill-mannered question.

**The Fourth Story (Neifile): Chichibio the Cook**
Currado Gianfigliazzi has his cook, Chichibio, roast a crane. Chichibio, enamored of a maid, Brunetta, gives her one of the crane's legs. When Currado demands to know what happened to the other leg, Chichibio claims cranes only have one leg. Currado threatens him and takes him to a river bank the next morning to prove him wrong. Chichibio points to cranes sleeping on one leg. When Currado shouts "Ho! Ho!", the cranes put down their second leg and fly away. Chichibio quickly retorts that Currado didn't shout at the cooked crane, implying it would have grown a second leg if he had. Currado, amused, turns his anger into laughter and forgives him.

**The Fifth Story (Pamfilo): Messer Forese da Rabatta and Master Giotto**
Messer Forese da Rabatta, an ugly but learned jurist, and Giotto, an ugly but brilliant painter, are riding together, both mud-splattered and ill-dressed. Forese jokingly asks Giotto if a stranger would believe him to be the world's finest painter. Giotto retorts that the same stranger, upon seeing Forese, wouldn't believe he even knew his ABCs. Forese, realizing the jab at his own ugliness, acknowledges Giotto's cleverness.

**The Sixth Story (Fiammetta): Michele Scalza**
Michele Scalza, a witty young Florentine, bets some companions that the "Cadgers" (beggars) of Florence are the noblest and oldest gentlemen. He proves his point by arguing that God created the Cadgers first, "when He first began to learn to draw," which explains their often-misshapen features, while other men were made after God had more practice. His companions, amused by this ridiculous but clever argument, declare he has won the wager.

**The Seventh Story (Filostrato): Madam Filippa**
In Prato, a law dictates that women found in adultery must be burned. Madam Filippa is caught by her husband, Rinaldo, with her lover, Lazzerino. Rinaldo accuses her in court. Filippa, with remarkable courage and wit, argues that the law is unjust because women were not consulted in its making. She then asks her husband if she ever denied him sexual satisfaction. He admits she never did. Filippa then asks the Provost what she was supposed to do with her "remainder" if her husband was satisfied. The townspeople, amused and impressed, agree with her, the law is modified to apply only to women who commit adultery for money, and Filippa is acquitted.

**The Eighth Story (Emilia): Fresco's Niece**
Fresco da Celatico has a vain, haughty, and critical niece, Ciesca. She constantly complains about how "disagreeable" everyone she meets is. Fresco, tired of her airs, tells her, "My lass, if disagreeable folk be so distasteful to thee as thou sayest, never mirror thyself in the glass, so thou wouldst live merry." Ciesca, too foolish to understand his subtle insult about her own unpleasantness, dismisses his advice.

**The Ninth Story (Lauretta): Guido Cavalcanti**
Guido Cavalcanti, a renowned Florentine philosopher, is often lost in abstract thought. Messer Betto Brunelleschi and his companions, believing Guido is a freethinker who doubts God, approach him among some ancient tombs and joke, "Guido, thou refusest to be of our company; but, harkye, whenas thou shalt have found that God is not, what wilt thou have accomplished?" Guido, quick-witted, replies, "Gentlemen, you may say what you will to me in your own house," then deftly leaps over a tomb to escape them. Messer Betto explains to his bewildered companions that Guido meant the tombs were "our house" (the house of the dead), implying that they, being ignorant, were no better than dead.

**The Tenth Story (Dioneo): Fra Cipolla**
Fra Cipolla, a jovial and cunning friar, promises the gullible villagers of Certaldo that he will show them a feather from the Archangel Gabriel. Two mischievous young men, Giovanni and Biagio, steal the feather from his reliquary (a casket) and replace it with coals. During his sermon, Fra Cipolla opens the casket, discovers the coals, but, without missing a beat, improvises a magnificent and hilarious tale of his travels to exotic lands, claiming he mistakenly brought the "coals wherewith Saint Lawrence was roasted," which he also possesses. He attributes the mix-up to divine will, as St. Lawrence's feast day is approaching. He then uses the coals to make crosses on the villagers' foreheads, earning many offerings. The young men, witnessing his incredible wit, are impressed and later return his feather.

**Day the Sixth Conclusion:**
Dioneo's story entertains everyone. Elisa, having completed her reign, passes the crown to Dioneo. Dioneo, accepting the role, jokes about his "kingdom." He sets the theme for Day 7: "the tricks which, or for love or for their own preservation, women have heretofore played their husbands, with or without the latter's cognizance thereof." He defends the theme against objections, arguing it is a time for liberty and amusement. The ladies then visit the "Ladies' Valley" and bathe in a lake. Pamfilo sings a love song.

**Day the Seventh**
The company moves to the Ladies' Valley, enjoying the natural beauty, dining by the lake, and then reassembling for storytelling. Dioneo, as king, commands Emilia to begin.

**The First Story (Emilia): Gianni Lotteringhi**
Gianni Lotteringhi, a simple-minded wool-comber, is easily fooled by his discreet wife, Tessa, who is having an affair with Federigo. They use a signal: an ass's skull in a vineyard, turned towards Florence means Federigo can come, towards Fiesole means Gianni is home. One night, Gianni unexpectedly returns while Federigo is waiting outside. Tessa, feigning sleep, then fear of a "phantom" at the door, convinces Gianni to help her perform an "exorcism" prayer. This prayer, cleverly designed by Tessa, explicitly directs Federigo to a hidden stash of food and wine in the garden (which the maid had prepared for their tryst), allowing him to escape with a meal. Gianni is none the wiser.

**The Second Story (Filostrato): Peronella**
Peronella, a poor but beautiful Neapolitan woman, has a lover, Giannello. Her husband, a mason, returns home unexpectedly while Giannello is with her. She quickly hides Giannello in a large empty vat. Her husband announces he has sold the vat for five florins. Peronella immediately claims she has already sold it for seven to a man who is currently inside inspecting it. Giannello emerges, feigning to be the buyer, complains the vat is dirty, and makes the husband scrape it clean from the inside. While her husband is inside the vat, Peronella and Giannello consummate their affair, with the husband completely unaware of the double deception.

**The Third Story (Elisa): Fra Rinaldo**
Fra Rinaldo, a Sienese monk, falls in love with his gossip (godmother of his child), Madam Agnesa. He convinces her that, due to his lesser relation to her child compared to her husband, it is less sinful for them to be lovers. One day, while they are together in her bedchamber, her husband returns. Agnesa quickly tells Rinaldo to hide. She then tells her husband that Fra Rinaldo is there to perform a conjuration to remove worms from their sick child. The husband, believing this, is relieved when the "exorcism" is complete, allowing Rinaldo to escape after making further arrangements for their affair.

**The Fourth Story (Lauretta): Tofano and Ghita**
Tofano, a rich but jealous Aretine, has a beautiful wife, Ghita. She, tired of his jealousy, takes a lover. To meet him, she gets Tofano drunk and puts him to bed. One night, Tofano feigns drunkenness to catch her. She goes to her lover. Tofano locks her out. Ghita, unable to re-enter, threatens to throw herself into a nearby well. She drops a large stone into the well. Tofano, believing she has jumped, rushes out to save her. Ghita slips back into the house, locks him out, and then scolds him from the window, accusing him of drunkenness and coming home late. Neighbors and her family believe her, blame Tofano, beat him, and take Ghita home. Tofano, realizing his folly and the futility of his jealousy, makes peace with her, granting her freedom if she's discreet.

**The Fifth Story (Fiammetta): A Jealous Husband and his Wife**
A rich merchant in Arimino is consumed by baseless jealousy, confining his beautiful wife. To escape her misery, she takes a lover, Filippo, a neighbor, communicating through a crack in the wall. As Christmas approaches, she asks her husband for permission to confess. He, suspicious, disguises himself as a priest and hears her confession. She "confesses" to loving a priest who magically enters her house nightly. The jealous husband, enraged, resolves to catch the priest. That night, he pretends to leave but hides to watch the door. The wife, knowing his plan, arranges for her lover to enter by the roof. While the husband waits outside, the wife and her lover are together. She later reveals she knew it was him, and he, fooled by her cleverness, abandons his jealousy.

**The Sixth Story (Pampinea): Madam Isabella and Leonetto**
Madam Isabella, a noble married lady, has a lover, Leonetto. She is also blackmailed into an affair with Messer Lambertuccio. One day, her husband is away, and she is with Leonetto. Lambertuccio arrives. She hides Leonetto. Lambertuccio enters. Then, her husband returns unexpectedly. Isabella, thinking quickly, tells Lambertuccio to draw his dagger and rush out, pretending to threaten an unknown man. Lambertuccio complies. Her husband, surprised, questions her. She fabricates a story about a fleeing stranger being chased by Lambertuccio. Her husband, believing Leonetto to be the threatened stranger, escorts him safely home. Isabella's husband remains fooled.

**The Seventh Story (Filomena): Lodovico and Beatrice**
Lodovico, a Florentine gentleman, falls in love with Madam Beatrice, wife of Messer Egano, a Bolognese nobleman. Lodovico takes service in Egano's household under the name "Anichino." Beatrice, drawn to his good looks and manners, eventually reciprocates his love. They arrange a tryst. Beatrice, to facilitate their affair and simultaneously test her husband, tells Egano that Anichino has propositioned her. She suggests Egano disguise himself as her and go to the garden at midnight to meet Anichino, so he can witness Anichino's disloyalty. Egano complies. Anichino, having been informed by Beatrice, then proceeds to "cudgel" the disguised Egano, pretending to rebuke him for propositioning his lady. Anichino then sleeps with Beatrice. Egano, bruised and fooled, believes Anichino is loyal and praises him.

**The Eighth Story (Neifile): Arriguccio and Sismonda**
Arriguccio, a jealous merchant, is married to Sismonda, who has a lover, Ruberto. Sismonda devises a system: a thread tied to her toe and hanging out the window. Ruberto pulls the thread to signal his arrival. One night, Arriguccio discovers the thread, cuts it, ties it to his own toe, and waits. Ruberto pulls, Arriguccio rushes out, and they fight. Meanwhile, Sismonda puts her maid in her place in the bed. Arriguccio returns, furiously beats and cuts the hair of the maid, believing it is Sismonda. He then calls Sismonda's brothers to witness her "infidelity." Sismonda, appearing unharmed and well-dressed, convinces her family that Arriguccio was drunk and imagined the whole incident, and accuses him of infidelity. Her family, believing her, reprimands Arriguccio, who is left confused and gives up his jealousy.

**The Ninth Story (Pamfilo): Lydia and Pyrrhus**
Lydia, wife of Nicostratus, loves Pyrrhus, her husband's servant. Pyrrhus, initially cautious, demands three proofs of her love: she must kill Nicostratus's favorite hawk in his presence, send Pyrrhus a lock of her husband's beard, and one of his teeth. Lydia cleverly fulfills each demand with plausible excuses (e.g., hawk robbed her time, beard pulling was a playful game, tooth was rotten). For the final proof, she brings Nicostratus and Pyrrhus to a pear tree. She tells Pyrrhus to climb it. From the tree, Pyrrhus pretends to see Nicostratus and Lydia making love below. Nicostratus, climbing the tree to see for himself, then "sees" Lydia and Pyrrhus making love (which they do while he is in the tree). Nicostratus is convinced the tree is enchanted and has it cut down, remaining fooled by his wife's cunning.

**The Tenth Story (Dioneo): Two Siennese and the Gossip**
Two Sienese friends, Tingoccio and Meuccio, promise that the first to die will return with news of the afterlife. Tingoccio secretly falls in love with his gossip, Mistress Mita, and sleeps with her. He dies. His ghost appears to Meuccio, telling him about purgatory. Meuccio asks about the punishment for sleeping with a gossip. Tingoccio replies that in the afterlife, such actions are not counted as sins, causing Meuccio to mock his own previous restraint. This story, though not directly a trick played on a husband, explores the theme of deception and moral relativism.

**Day the Seventh Conclusion:**
Dioneo's story is met with laughter. Elisa, having completed her reign, passes the crown to Lauretta. Lauretta sets the theme for Day 8: "of the tricks that all day long women play men or men women or men one another," allowing for varied stories. The company enjoys bathing in a cool stream in the valley before returning to the palace. Filomena sings a song expressing longing in love.

**Day the Eighth**
The company enjoys their usual morning routine. Lauretta, as queen, commands Neifile to begin the day's stories.

**The First Story (Neifile): Gulfardo**
Gulfardo, a German soldier in Milan, falls in love with Madam Ambruogia, the wife of his friend Guasparruolo. Ambruogia demands 200 gold florins for her favors. Gulfardo, disgusted by her avarice, borrows the 200 florins from Guasparruolo himself. He then presents the money to Ambruogia in front of his friend, claiming it is for her husband. She takes it, believing it a discreet payment for her services. Gulfardo enjoys her favors. When Guasparruolo returns, Gulfardo tells him he repaid the loan to his wife, which Ambruogia cannot deny. Thus, Gulfardo enjoys her for free, and she effectively pays for her own adultery.

**The Second Story (Pamfilo): The Parish Priest of Varlungo**
A lusty priest in Varlungo desires Mistress Belcolore, a lively country woman. Her husband goes to Florence. The priest visits Belcolore, who demands five crowns for her favors. The priest, reluctant to pay, leaves his expensive cloak as a pledge. They make love. The next day, the priest, regretting losing his cloak, sends his clerk to borrow Belcolore's mortar and to demand his cloak back, claiming the boy left it as a "token." Belcolore's husband, present, orders her to return the cloak, unwittingly enabling the priest to retrieve it for free. Belcolore, though outwitted, eventually makes peace with the priest, securing his affections over time.

**The Third Story (Elisa): Calandrino and the Heliotrope**
Calandrino, a simple-minded painter, is tricked by his friends Bruno and Buffalmacco. Maso del Saggio tells Calandrino of the "heliotrope," a stone found in the Mugnone that makes the bearer invisible. Calandrino, excited, brings Bruno and Buffalmacco to search for black stones in the Mugnone. While Calandrino diligently collects black stones, believing he is invisible, his friends secretly follow him, pelting him with stones. They pretend not to see him. He returns home, his clothes filled with stones, believing the heliotrope worked. His wife scolds him for being late, revealing he is visible. Enraged, he beats her, blaming her for breaking the spell. Bruno and Buffalmacco arrive, confirm his belief that his wife's presence ruined the magic, and extort capons from him for their "help."

**The Fourth Story (Emilia): The Rector of Fiesole and Madam Piccarda**
A presumptuous old rector in Fiesole desires Madam Piccarda, a noble widow. She, disliking him, conspires with her brothers to shame him. She feigns interest and arranges a secret tryst in her dark bedchamber, warning him her brothers sleep nearby. Instead of herself, she puts her ugly, crooked maid, Ciutazza, in her bed. The rector, thinking he is with Piccarda, makes love to Ciutazza. Meanwhile, Piccarda's brothers bring the Bishop to the house. The Bishop discovers the rector in bed with Ciutazza. The rector is shamed, reprimanded, and punished. Piccarda successfully rids herself of his importunity.

**The Fifth Story (Filostrato): Three Young Men and a Marchegan Judge**
Maso del Saggio and his friends Ribi and Matteuzzo decide to prank Messer Niccola, an uncouth judge from the Marches of Ancona. They notice his ill-fitting breeches and the gaps in the bench where he sits. While the judge is hearing criminal cases, Maso and Ribi loudly simulate a dispute about stolen goods, distracting him. Matteuzzo, hidden beneath the bench, reaches up and pulls down Messer Niccola's breeches. The judge is exposed and humiliated in front of the entire court. The friends make their escape.

**The Sixth Story (Filomena): Bruno, Buffalmacco, and Calandrino's Pig**
Calandrino kills a pig. Bruno and Buffalmacco decide to steal it. They get Calandrino drunk at a tavern. He returns home, leaving his door open. They steal the pig. The next morning, Calandrino is distraught. His friends suggest an "ordeal by ginger boluses" to identify the thief among his neighbors. Bruno prepares regular boluses for everyone else but laces Calandrino's with aloes. During the "ordeal," Calandrino spits out his bitter boluses, making it appear he is the thief. His friends then extort two pairs of capons from him to keep his "crime" secret from his wife.

**The Seventh Story (Pampinea): Rinieri and Elena**
Rinieri, a scholar returned from Paris, falls in love with the haughty widow Elena. She, to amuse herself and her true lover, cruelly makes Rinieri spend a freezing winter night in her snow-filled courtyard, while she is inside with her lover. Rinieri's love turns to hatred. Later, Elena's lover abandons her. Desperate, she seeks Rinieri's help, believing him a necromancer, to win back her lover. Rinieri agrees, but plans a cruel revenge. He instructs her to bathe naked in a river at night and then stand naked on an uninhabited tower, turning north, to perform a conjuration. He removes the ladder, stranding her. She suffers all day from sun, thirst, and insects. Rinieri eventually reveals his revenge, relishing her torment before sending a peasant to rescue her. The maid breaks her thigh in the rescue. Elena, humbled, gives up her mockery and love.

**The Eighth Story (Fiammetta): Spinelloccio and Zeppa**
Spinelloccio and Zeppa, two close Sienese friends, each have beautiful wives. Spinelloccio has an affair with Zeppa's wife. Zeppa discovers them. Instead of a public confrontation, he plans a measured revenge. He instructs his wife to invite Spinelloccio for a tryst, then hide him in a chest when Zeppa returns. Zeppa then invites Spinelloccio's wife to dinner. He takes her into the bedchamber and seduces her, lying with her on the very chest where her husband, Spinelloccio, is hidden. Spinelloccio overhears and feels everything. Afterwards, Zeppa reveals Spinelloccio. Spinelloccio, acknowledging the fairness of the tit-for-tat revenge, proposes that they share their wives, which they all agree to, living in harmony.

**The Ninth Story (Emilia): Master Simone and the Countess of Jakes**
Master Simone, a vain and foolish physician, is befriended by the painters Bruno and Buffalmacco. They convince him that they belong to a secret society that magically obtains riches and women. Simone, eager to join, boasts of his own "wisdom" and offers to bring beautiful women. They instruct him to dress in finery and wait on a tomb at Santa Maria Novella. Buffalmacco, disguised as a horned "wild man," frightens Simone, then carries him into a trench full of human waste (the "Countess of Jakes's" domain). Simone is covered in filth. His wife berates him, believing he was with another woman. Bruno and Buffalmacco, feigning sympathy, show him fake bruises (from a supposed beating during the "roving") and extort hospitality from him to keep his humiliation secret.

**The Tenth Story (Dioneo): Salabaetto and Biancofiore**
Salabaetto, a Florentine merchant, is in Palermo with goods. Biancofiore, a cunning courtesan known for swindling merchants, seduces him. She uses lavish hospitality and feigned love to win his trust. She then fabricates a story of a brother in danger, needing 1000 florins, and borrows 500 from Salabaetto, promising quick repayment. When she delays, he realizes he's been conned. Advised by a wise friend, Canigiano, Salabaetto returns to Palermo with barrels supposedly full of oil (but mostly seawater) and bales of tow, making a show of vast new wealth. Biancofiore, hoping to gain much more, repays his 500 florins. Salabaetto then flees, leaving her with the worthless merchandise, thus getting his revenge and recovering his money.

**Day the Eighth Conclusion:**
Dioneo's story is enjoyed. Lauretta passes the crown to Emilia. Emilia sets a free theme for Day 9: "each discoursing according as it pleaseth him and of that which is most to his liking." The company enjoys a variety of diversions, including singing and dancing.

**Day the Ninth**
The company enjoys an early morning walk, observing tame wild animals, before returning for their meal and afternoon storytelling. Emilia, as queen, commands Filomena to begin.

**The First Story (Filomena): Madam Francesca**
Madam Francesca, a beautiful widow in Pistoia, is courted by two Florentine exiles, Rinuccio and Alessandro. Tired of their importunity, and not loving them, she devises a trick to rid herself of them. She sets an impossible condition: Alessandro must enter a tomb to take the place of a recently buried, notoriously ugly man (Scannadio), feigning death. Rinuccio must then retrieve "Scannadio's" body from the tomb and bring it to her. Both men agree, driven by love. Alessandro, terrified, enters the tomb. Rinuccio, also afraid, retrieves Alessandro. The city watch intervenes. Both men flee, abandoning their task. Francesca, amused and relieved, dismisses them for failing to fulfill her conditions.

**The Second Story (Elisa): The Abbess and Isabetta**
In a Lombard convent, the nun Isabetta secretly takes a lover. Other nuns discover her and report it to the Abbess, Madam Usimbalda, hoping to catch Isabetta in the act. The Abbess, who is herself with a priest, rushes out in the dark, mistakenly putting the priest's breeches on her head instead of her coif. She bursts into Isabetta's cell, finding her with her lover. Isabetta, seeing the breeches on the Abbess's head, cleverly tells her to "tie up her coif." The Abbess, realizing her own hypocrisy is exposed to everyone, changes her tone. She acknowledges the impossibility of resisting natural desires and grants all nuns discretion in their private lives. Isabetta and her lover are saved from punishment.

**The Third Story (Filostrato): Calandrino is Made to Believe He is Pregnant**
Calandrino inherits 200 crowns and brags about buying land. His friends Bruno, Buffalmacco, and Nello conspire to trick him out of money. Nello, then Bruno and Buffalmacco, tell Calandrino he looks unwell. He believes he is sick. They send his urine to Master Simone, a physician, who is in on the joke. Simone "diagnoses" Calandrino as pregnant, claiming it's due to his wife's sexual assertiveness. Calandrino is horrified. Simone prescribes a "ptisan" (laxative) and demands three pairs of capons and five crowns for medicines. Calandrino, desperate to avoid giving birth, pays. He takes the laxative, feels better, and believes he was "unbegotten" of his pregnancy, blaming his wife. His friends feast on the capons.

**The Fourth Story (Neifile): Cecco Fortarrigo and Cecco Angiolieri**
Two Sienese men, both named Cecco, are friends and gamblers. Angiolieri receives an advance from his father for a journey and hires Fortarrigo as a servant. At an inn, while Angiolieri sleeps, Fortarrigo gambles away his own money, then steals Angiolieri's money and loses that too. Angiolieri awakens to find his money gone. Fortarrigo then pretends to be concerned about his pawned doublet and, seeing Angiolieri ride off, chases him, crying "Thief!" Countrymen, believing the shirtless Fortarrigo, stop Angiolieri. Fortarrigo, with the countrymen's help, strips Angiolieri, takes his clothes and horse, and leaves him stranded. Fortarrigo returns to Siena boasting of his "winnings." Angiolieri, humiliated, eventually returns home.

**The Fifth Story (Fiammetta): Calandrino and Niccolosa**
Calandrino falls in love with Niccolosa, a courtesan, at a mansion where he and his friends are painting. Bruno, Buffalmacco, and Nello conspire to exploit his infatuation. Bruno convinces Calandrino that Niccolosa loves him and provides him with a "talismanic script" that will make her follow him if he touches her with it. Nello secretly informs Calandrino's wife, Tessa, about the affair. Calandrino uses the "talisman" on Niccolosa (who is in on the prank) and she follows him to a barn. Tessa bursts in, catching Niccolosa astride Calandrino. Niccolosa flees. Tessa violently beats Calandrino, accusing him of infidelity. Bruno and Buffalmacco feign surprise and, after appeasing Tessa, advise Calandrino to leave Florence to avoid further trouble. Calandrino, humiliated, ends his infatuation.

**The Sixth Story (Pamfilo): Pinuccio and Niccolosa**
Two young gentlemen, Pinuccio and Adriano, lodge at a poor inn in Mugnone. Pinuccio loves the host's daughter, Niccolosa. In the night, Pinuccio goes to Niccolosa's bed. The host's wife, awakened by a cat, inadvertently moves her baby's cradle. Adriano, needing to relieve himself, moves the cradle to his own bed. The wife, returning in the dark, mistakes Adriano's bed for her husband's due to the cradle's new position and climbs in with Adriano. Pinuccio, returning from Niccolosa, mistakes the host's bed for Adriano's and tells the host about his night with Niccolosa. The host is furious. The wife, realizing her error, cleverly pretends Pinuccio was dreaming. Adriano plays along. The host is fooled, and the lovers escape scandal.

**The Seventh Story (Pampinea): Talano di Molese's Dream**
Talano di Molese dreams that a fierce wolf attacks his froward wife, Margarita, mangling her neck and face. He warns her not to go to the wood that day. Margarita, believing he's trying to keep her from a supposed lover, defies him and goes to the wood. A wolf indeed attacks her, disfiguring her as in the dream. She is rescued but remains ugly, regretting her stubbornness and disbelief of her husband's dream.

**The Eighth Story (Lauretta): Biondello and Ciacco**
Ciacco, a gluttonous Florentine, is tricked by Biondello, another spunger, into expecting a lavish dinner of lampreys at Messer Corso Donati's house. Ciacco arrives to a meager meal. He plots revenge. He sends a merchant to Messer Filippo Argenti, a famously choleric man, with a vulgar message in Biondello's name, asking Filippo to "rubify" a flask for his "minions." Filippo, enraged, encounters Biondello and brutally beats him. Biondello realizes Ciacco's revenge.
